{{Infobox ancient site |name = Amalq Qatih |native_name = |alternate_name = Amlaq el Qatih |image = |alt = |caption = |map_type = |map_alt = |latitude = |longitude = |map_size = |location = {{convert|2.5|km|mi}} northwest of [[Baaloul]], {{convert|5|km|mi}} north of [[Qaraoun]], [[Lebanon]] |region = |coordinates = |type = |part_of = |length = |width = |area = |height = |builder = |material = |built = |abandoned = |epochs = [[Heavy Neolithic]] |cultures = [[Qaraoun culture]] |dependency_of = |occupants = |event = |excavations = 1955 |archaeologists = [[Henri Fleisch]], [[Maurice Tallon]] |condition = |ownership = |management = |public_access = Unknown |website = |notes = }} '''Amlaq Qatih''' or '''Amlaq el Qatih''' is a [[Heavy Neolithic]] archaeological site of the [[Qaraoun culture]] that is located {{convert|2.5|km|mi}} northwest of [[Baaloul]], {{convert|5|km|mi}} north of [[Qaraoun]], [[Lebanon]].<ref name="Moore">{{cite book|last=Moore|first=A.M.T.|title=The Neolithic of the Levant|publisher=Oxford University, Unpublished Ph.D. Thesis|year=1978|pages=444–446|url=http://ancientneareast.tripod.com/185.html}}</ref><ref name="CopelandWescombe1966">{{cite book|author1=L. Copeland|author2=P. Wescombe|title=Inventory of Stone-Age Sites in Lebanon: North, South and East-Central Lebanon, p. 22|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qhPRQwAACAAJ|accessdate=29 August 2011|year=1966|publisher=Impr. Catholique}}</ref>
The site was discovered and collections made by [[Henri Fleisch]] and [[Maurice Tallon]] in 1955. Materials recovered were found to be of a cream-coloured, cherty type of flint and were suggested to date from [[Acheulian]], [[Heavy Neolithic]] and normal [[Neolithic]] periods and included a few [[Levallois technique|Levallois]] cores.<ref name="CopelandWescombe1966"/>
==References== {{Reflist}} {{Western Beqaa District}} {{Heavy Neolithic sites}} {{Archaeological sites in Lebanon}} {{Portal|Lebanon|Archaeology|Ancient Near East}}

page.title: An Attempt at a Critique of All Revelation

revision.text:
{{italic title}} '''''An Attempt at a Critique of All Revelation''''' ({{lang-de|Versuch einer Critik<!--[sic]--><ref>''Kritik'' in [[modern German]].</ref> aller Offenbarung}}; 1792) was the first published work by [[Johann Gottlieb Fichte]]. It was briefly mistaken by the public to be a fourth Critique by [[Immanuel Kant]], and thereby gained Fichte much philosophical fame.
In this work, Fichte argued that any [[revelation]] in relation to [[God]] must be consistent with [[morality]], which was against many aspects of orthodox [[Christian]] belief at the time.<ref name="iep">[http://www.iep.utm.edu/f/fichtejg.htm Johann Gottlieb Fichte [Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy]<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==Notes and references== <references/>
==External links== ;Text in English * Johann Fichte, [http://www.cambridge.org/us/academic/subjects/philosophy/philosophy-texts/fichte-attempt-critique-all-revelation ''An Attempt at a Critique of All Revelation''], Cambridge, 2010 * [https://archive.org/details/johanngottliebf19fichgoog ''Versuch einer Kritik aller Offenbarung''], the original German-language text
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Attempt at a Critique of All Revelation, An}} [[Category:1792 books]] [[Category:Books by Johann Gottlieb Fichte]] [[Category:German non-fiction books]] [[Category:Debut books]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2016}} {{About||the [[Hispanic and Latino Americans|Latino]] population of Asian descent living in or native to the United States|Asian Hispanic and Latino Americans|the population in Asia of Latin American descent|Latin American Asian}} {{infobox ethnic group |group = Asian Latin Americans |image = |caption = |population = {{circa|4,500,000}} |popplace = |region1 = {{flagcountry|Brazil}} |pop1 = 2,200,000 |ref1 ={{cite conference|author1=Alessandra Duarte|author2=Flávio Freire|title=População asiática aumentou 173% no Brasil, segundo o Censo de 2010|trans-title=Asian population climbed 173% in Brazil, according to 2010 Census|language=pt|publisher=[[O Globo]]|date=30 May 2011|url=http://oglobo.globo.com/pais/mat/2011/04/30/populacao-asiatica-aumentou-173-no-brasil-segundo-censo-de-2010-924357980.asp|accessdate=11 January 2016}}[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20080115i1.html=search.japantimes.co.jp Japan, Brazil mark a century of settlement, family ties| The Japan Times Online] |region2 = {{flagcountry|Peru}} |pop2 = 1,560,000 |region3 = {{flagcountry|Mexico}} |pop3 = 1,230,000 |region4 = {{flagcountry|Venezuela}} |pop4 = 500,000 |region6 = {{flagcountry|Argentina}} |pop6 =195,000 |ref6 = |region7 = {{flagcountry|Panama}} |pop7 = 140,000 |ref7 = |region8 = {{flagcountry|Colombia}} |pop8 = 114,240 |ref8 = CIA World Factbook. Cuba. 2008. May 15, 2008. Cuba Puerto Rico Dominican Republic . |langs = '''European Languages:'''
[[Spanish Language|Spanish]]{{·}} [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]]{{·}} [[English language|English]]
'''Asian Languages:'''
[[Arabic]] {{*}} [[Chinese language|Chinese]]{{·}}[[Hindustani language|Hindustani (Hindi-Urdu)]]{{·}}[[Tamil language|Tamil]]{{·}}[[Telugu language|Telugu]]{{·}}[[Japanese language|Japanese]]{{·}}[[Korean language|Korean]]{{·}}[[Punjabi language|Punjabi]]{{·}}[[Urdu language|Urdu]]{{•}}[[Filipino language|Filipino]]{{·}}[[Bengali language|Bengali]]{{·}}[[Vietnamese language|Vietnamese]] |rels = [[Buddhism]]{{·}}[[Christianity]]{{·}}[[Hinduism]]{{·}}[[Islam]]{{·}}[[Shintoism]]{{·}}[[Sikhism]]{{·}}[[Taoism]]{{·}}[[Zorastrianism]]{{·}}[[Jainism]] |related = [[Latino]], [[Hispanic]], [[Asian people|Asian]], [[Spaniards]], [[Portuguese people|Portuguese]], [[White Latin Americans|European Latin Americans]], [[Asian Hispanic and Latino Americans]], [[Latin American Asian]], [[Asian Caribbean]], [[Indo-Caribbean]], [[Chinese Caribbean]] }} '''Asian Latin Americans''' are [[Latin Americans]] of [[East Asia]]n, [[Southeast Asia]]n or [[South Asia]]n descent. West Asians are typically considered to be White. Asian Latin Americans have a centuries-long history in the region, starting with [[Overseas Filipino|Filipino]]s in the 16th century. The peak of Asian immigration occurred in the 19th and 20th centuries, however. There are currently more than four million Asian Latin Americans, nearly 1% of [[Latin America]]'s population. [[Overseas Chinese|Chinese]] and [[Japanese people|Japanese]] are the group's largest ancestries; other major ones include [[Overseas Filipino|Filipinos]], [[Koreans]], and [[Indian people|Indians]]. [[Brazil]] is home to the largest population of Asian Latin Americans, at some 2.2 million.{{cite web|url=http://www.ibge.gov.br/home/estatistica/populacao/trabalhoerendimento/pnad2006/brasilpnad2006.pdf|format=PDF|title=Pesquisa Nacional por Amostra de Domicílios 2006|trans-title=National Sample Household Survey 2006|language=pt|publisher=Brazilian Institute of Geography and Statistics|date=2007|volume=47|accessdate=10 June 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080611203345/http://www.ibge.gov.br/home/estatistica/populacao/trabalhoerendimento/pnad2006/brasilpnad2006.pdf|archivedate=11 June 2008|postscript=: See Table 1.2}}[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20080115i1.html=search.japantimes.co.jp Japan, Brazil mark a century of settlement, family ties | The Japan Times Online] The highest ratio of any country in the region is 5%,{{cite web|url=http://www.ocac.gov.tw/english/public/public.asp?selno%3D1163%26no%3D1163%26level%3DB |title=The Ranking of Ethnic Chinese Population |publisher=Overseas Community Affairs Council, Republic of China (Taiwan) |accessdate=26 July 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131123193905/http://www.ocac.gov.tw/english/public/public.asp?selno=1163&no=1163&level=B |archivedate=23 November 2013 }} in [[Peru]]. There has been notable emigration from these communities in recent decades, so that there are now hundreds of thousands of people of Asian Latin American origin in both [[Japan]] and the [[United States]]. ==History== The first Asian Latin Americans were [[Overseas Filipino|Filipino]]s who made their way to Latin America (primarily [[Filipino Cubans|to Cuba]] and [[Mexico]], and secondarily to [[Colombia]], [[Panama]] and [[Peru]]) in the 16th century, as sailors, crews, prisoners, slaves, adventurers and soldiers during the [[History of the Philippines (1521-1898)|Spanish colonial period of the Philippines]]. For two and a half centuries (between 1565 and 1815) many Filipinos sailed on the [[Manila Galleon|Manila-Acapulco Galleons]], assisting in the [[Spanish Empire]]'s monopoly in trade. Some of these sailors never returned to the [[Philippines]], and many of their descendants can be found in small communities around [[Baja California]], [[Sonora]], [[Mexico City]], [[Lima, Peru|Peru]] and others, thus making Filipinos the oldest Asian ethnic group in Latin-America. While South Asians had been present in various forms in Latin America for centuries by the 1800s, it was in this century that the flow into the region spiked dramatically. This rapid influx of hundreds of thousands of mainly male South Asians was due to the need for indentured servants. This is largely tied to the [http://www.nationalarchives.gov.uk/caribbeanhistory/slavery-negotiating-freedom.htm abolition of black slavery in the Caribbean colonies in 1834]. Without the promise of free labor, and a hostile working class on their hands, the Dutch colonial authorities had to find a solution – cheap Asian labor.{{Cite book|title=A History of Modern Latin America|last=Meade|first=Teresa|publisher=John Wiley & Sons, Inc.|year=2010|isbn=978-1-118-77248-5|location=West Sussex, UK|pages=141-142}} Many of these immigrant populations became such fixtures in their adopted countries that they acquired names of their own. For example, the Chinese men who labored in agricultural work became known as “[[Coolie|Coolies]]”. While these imported Asian laborers were initially just replacement for agricultural slave labor, they gradually began to enter other sectors as the economy evolved. Before long, they had entered more urban work and the service sector. In certain areas, these populations assimilated into the minority populations, adding yet another definition to go on a [[casta]].   In some areas, these new populations caused conflict. In northern Mexico, tensions became inevitable when the United States began to [[Chinese Exclusion Act#The "Driving Out" period|shut off Chinese immigration]] in the early 1880s. Many who were originally bound for the USA were re-routed to Mexico. The rapid increase in population and rise to middle/upper class standing generated strong resentment among existing residents. These tensions lead to riots. In the state of Sonora, the entire Chinese population was expelled in 1929. Today, the overwhelming majority of Asian Latin Americans are of [[Overseas Chinese|Chinese]], [[Japanese diaspora|Japanese]], or [[Korean diaspora|Korean]] descent. Japanese migration mostly came to a halt after World War II (with the exception of [[Japanese settlement in the Dominican Republic]]), while Korean migration mostly came to an end by the 1980s and Chinese migration remains ongoing in a number of countries. Settlement of war refugees has been extremely minor: a few dozen ex-North Korean soldiers went to Argentina and Chile after the [[Korean War]],{{Cite book|last=Bialogorski|first=Mirta|chapter=La comunidad coreana - Argentina - Logros de una inmigración reciente|pages=275–296|title=Cuando Oriente llegó a América: Contribuciones de inmigrantes chinos, japoneses, y coreanos|publisher=Banco Interamericano De Desarrollo|year=2005|isbn=978-1-931003-73-5}}{{Cite book|last=Park|first=Chae-soon|chapter=La emigración coreana en América Latina y sus perspectivas|title=Segundo Congreso del Consejo de Estudios Latinoamericanos de Asia y de Oceania|publisher=Latin American Studies Association of Korea|publication-place=Seoul|year=2007|url=http://www.lasak.or.kr/CELAOfiles/papers/Session3/Park%20Chae%20Soon%5BSession3-2%5D.pdf|accessdate=2008-09-27|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722141305/http://www.lasak.or.kr/CELAOfiles/papers/Session3/Park%20Chae%20Soon%5BSession3-2%5D.pdf|archivedate=22 July 2011|df=dmy-all}} and some Hmong went to [[French Guiana]] after the [[Vietnam War]].{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/asia-pacific/3498056.stm | work=BBC News | title=Hmong's new lives in Caribbean | date=2004-03-10 | accessdate=2010-04-25}} == Roles in Labor == Asian Latin Americans served various roles during their time as low wage workers in Latin America. In the second half of the nineteenth century, nearly a quarter of a million Chinese migrants in Cuba worked primarily on sugar plantations. The Chinese "coolies" who migrated to Peru took up work on the Andean Railroad or the Guano Fields. Over time the Chinese progressed to acquiring work in urban centers as tradesmen, restaurateurs, and in the service industry. By the second decade of the nineteenth century, approximately 25,000 Chinese migrants in Mexico found relative success with small businesses, government bureaucracy, and intellectual circles. In the 1830's the British and Dutch colonial governments also imported South Asians to work as indentured servants to places such as Trinidad and Tobago, Suriname,Curaçao, and British Guiana (later renamed Guayana). At the turn of the nineteenth and twentieth centuries, Japanese immigrants reached Brazil and Peru. Much like the Chinese, the Japanese often worked as indentured servants and low wage workers for planters. Japanese work contracts were notably more short term than those of the Chinese and the process was closely monitored by the Japanese government to dissuade abuse and foul play. In both cases, the influx of Asian migrant workers was to fill the void left in the Latin American work forces after the abolition of slavery. Employers of all kinds were desperate for a low cost replacement for their slaves so those who did not participate in any illegal slave operations turned to the Asian migrants.{{Cite book|title=A History of Modern Latin America 1800 to the Present|last=Meade|first=Teresa|publisher=John Wiley & Sons. Inc.|year=2016|isbn=|location=|pages=141}} ==Geographic distribution== Four and a half million Latin Americans (almost 1% of the total population of Latin America) are of Asian descent. The number may be millions higher, even more so if all who have partial ancestry are included. For example, Asian Peruvians are estimated at 5% of the population there, but one source places the number of all Peruvians with at least ''some'' [[Overseas Chinese|Chinese]] ancestry at 5 million, which equates to 20% of the country's total population.{{cite web |url=http://taste-of-peru.com/peruvian_culture/chinese.php |title=Peruvian Culinary Culture: Chinese Influence |publisher=Taste of Peru |date= |accessdate=13 November 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130927041027/http://taste-of-peru.com/peruvian_culture/chinese.php |archivedate=27 September 2013 |df=dmy-all }} Most who are of Japanese descent reside in Brazil, Peru, Argentina, Mexico, Bolivia, and Paraguay while significant populations of Chinese ancestry are found in [[Peru]], [[Venezuela]], [[Brazil]], [[Colombia]], [[Argentina]], [[Cuba]], [[Dominican Republic]], [[Panama]], [[Puerto Rico]], [[Mexico]], and [[Costa Rica]] (where they make up about 1% of the total population). [[Nicaragua]] is home to 12,000 ethnic Chinese; the majority reside in [[Managua]] and on the [[Caribbean]] coast. Smaller communities of Chinese, numbering just in the hundreds or thousands, are also found in [[Ecuador]] and various other Latin American countries. Most Korean communities are in [[Brazil]], [[Mexico]], [[Argentina]], [[Guatemala]], [[Paraguay]], [[Colombia]], [[Ecuador]] and [[Chile]]. There are around 12,918 living in Guatemala. There is also a [[Hmong people|Hmong]] community in Argentina. [[Colombia]], [[Peru]], [[Argentina]], [[Brazil]], [[Panama]], and [[Venezuela]] also have [[Non-resident Indian and person of Indian origin|Asian Indian]] communities. Japanese Peruvians have a considerable economic position in Peru.Lama, Abraham. Asian Times. Home is where the heartbreak is. 1999. September 6, 2006.. Many past and present Peruvian Cabinet members are ethnic Asians, but most particularly Japanese Peruvians have made up large portions of Peru's cabinet members and former president [[Alberto Fujimori]] is of Japanese ancestry who is currently the only Asian Latin American to have ever served as the head of any Latin American nation. [[Brazil]] is home to the largest [[Japanese diaspora|Japanese]] community outside [[Japan]], numbering about 1.7 million with ancestry alone. Brazil is also home to 10,000 Indians, 5,000 Vietnamese, 4,500 Afghans, 2,900 Indonesians and 1,000 Filipinos. ==Emigrant communities== ===Canada=== Canada has been a destination for Asian Latin American emigration. The immigrants usually settle in the largest cities, such as [[Vancouver]] and [[Toronto]] and integrate into the overall [[Asian Canadians|Asian Canadian]] communities. ===Japan=== {{Main|Dekasegi}} [[Brazilians in Japan|Japanese Brazilian immigrants to Japan]] numbered 250,000 in 2004, constituting Japan's second-largest immigrant population.{{cite web|url=http://www.international.ucla.edu/article.asp?parentid=6996 |title=Japanese Brazilian Return Migration and the Making of Japan's Newest Immigrant Minority |accessdate=2008-03-21 |author=Richard Gunde |date=2004-01-27 |publisher=UCLA International Institute |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120204213520/http://www.international.ucla.edu/article.asp?parentid=6996 |archivedate=4 February 2012 }} Their experiences bear similarities to those of Japanese Peruvian immigrants, who are often relegated to low income jobs typically occupied by foreigners. ===United States=== {{Main|Asian Hispanic and Latino Americans}} Most Asian Latin Americans who have migrated to the [[United States]] live in the largest cities, often in [[Asian American]] or [[Hispanic and Latino Americans|Hispanic and Latino]] communities in the [[Greater Los Angeles area]], [[New York metropolitan area]], [[Chicago metropolitan area]], [[San Francisco Bay area]], [[Greater Houston]], the [[San Diego County, California|San Diego area]], [[Imperial Valley (California)|Imperial Valley]], [[California]], [[Dallas-Fort Worth]] and [[South Florida]] (mainly [[Chinese Cubans]]). They and their descendants are sometimes known as Asian Hispanics and Asian Latinos. In the [[United States Census 2000|2000 US Census]], 119,829 Hispanic or Latino [[Demographics of the United States|Americans]] identified as being of Asian race alone.{{cite web |url=https://www.census.gov/prod/2001pubs/cenbr01-1.pdf |format=PDF|title=Overview of Race and Hispanic Origin: 2000 |publisher=U.S. Census Bureau}} In 2006 the Census Bureau's [[American Community Survey]] estimated them at 154,694,{{cite web|url=http://factfinder.census.gov/servlet/DTTable?_bm=y&-ds_name=ACS_2006_EST_G00_&-CONTEXT=dt&-mt_name=ACS_2006_EST_G2000_B03002&-redoLog=false&-currentselections=PEP_2006_EST_G2006_T004_2006&-geo_id=01000US&-format=&-_lang=en|title=B03002. HISPANIC OR LATINO ORIGIN BY RACE - Universe: TOTAL POPULATION|work=2006 American Community Survey|accessdate=2008-03-21|publisher=U.S. Census Bureau}}{{dead link|date=October 2016}}{{cbignore}} while its Population Estimates, which are official, put them at 277,704.{{cite web|url=http://factfinder.census.gov/servlet/DTTable?_bm=y&-ds_name=PEP_2006_EST&-CONTEXT=dt&-mt_name=PEP_2006_EST_G2006_T004_2006&-redoLog=false&-currentselections=PEP_2006_EST_G2006_T004_2006&-geo_id=01000US&-format=&-_lang=en |title=T4-2006. Hispanic or Latino By Race [15] |accessdate=2008-03-21 |work=Data Set: 2006 Population Estimates |publisher=U.S. Census Bureau}}{{dead link|date=October 2016}}{{cbignore}} Some notable Americans of Asian Hispanic/Latino heritage include [[Harry Shum Jr.]], [[Franklin Chang-Diaz]], [[Carlos Galvan]], [[Kelis]], [[Kirk Acevedo]] and [[Chino Moreno]]. In the United States, there are Facebook groups that are devoted to Asian Hispanics in New York,{{cite web |url=https://www.facebook.com/groups/5363933778/ |title= LatinAsians in New York |accessdate=2010-09-01 |publisher=Facebook}} California{{cite web |url=https://www.facebook.com/groups/16723867462/ |title= LatinAsians in CA |accessdate=2010-09-01 |publisher=Facebook}} and Bay Area.{{cite web |url=https://www.facebook.com/groups/105918219450966/ |title= LatinAsians in Bay Area |accessdate=2010-09-01 |publisher=Facebook}} ==Composition== {|class="wikitable, sortable" |+Asian Latin American population (incomplete data) |- style="background:#efefef;" !Country ![[Overseas Chinese|Chinese]] ![[Non-resident Indian and person of Indian origin|Indian]]{{Cite book|last=Singhvi|first=L. M.|chapter=Other Countries of Central and South America|title=Report of the High Level Committee on the Indian Diaspora|publisher=Ministry of External Affairs|publication-place=New Delhi|url=http://indiandiaspora.nic.in/diasporapdf/chapter19.pdf|year=2000|access-date=29 August 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303175035/http://indiandiaspora.nic.in/diasporapdf/chapter19.pdf|archive-date=3 March 2016|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}; revision.text:
[[File:Bokerley Dyke, Martin Down - geograph.org.uk - 674000.jpg|thumb|right|Bokerley Dyke on Martin Down]] '''Bokerley Dyke''' (or '''Bokerley Ditch''') is a [[Romano-British]] defensive dyke {{convert|3.25|mi|km|1}} long in north east [[Dorset]], [[England]], near the villages of [[Woodyates]] and [[Pentridge]].
Bokerley Dyke may have originated in the [[Bronze Age Britain|Bronze Age]] or [[British Iron Age|Early Iron Age]] and formed a political and cultural boundary.<ref name="pastscape">[http://www.pastscape.org.uk/hob.aspx?hob_id=906268 Bokerley Dyke] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120930231906/http://www.pastscape.org.uk/hob.aspx?hob_id=906268 |date=September 30, 2012 }}, Pastscape</ref> It was cut through by a Roman Road ([[Ackling Dyke]] running between [[Old Sarum]] and [[Badbury Rings]]) in the 1st century.<ref name="pastscape"/>
In the 4th century it was remodelled and bought back into use, and excavations show that the Roman road was blocked.<ref name="pastscape"/><ref name="putnam">Bill Putnam, (2000), ''Discover Dorset: The Romans'', page 71. The Dovecote Press</ref> A coin of [[Valens]] dates this activity to shortly after 364 AD.<ref name="pastscape"/> It may have been built in 367-8 AD when Roman sources report that Britain was attacked by Picts, Scots and Saxons in a supposed [[Great Conspiracy]].<ref name="putnam"/> The Roman road was later reopened, but the dyke may have continued in use after the cessation of the Roman rule and still forms part of a boundary between the counties of [[Dorset]] and [[Hampshire]].<ref name="pastscape"/>
Bokerley Dyke is continuous with [[Grim's Ditch]] which runs into Hampshire.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Bokerley Dyke}} *{{gbmapping|SU042192}}
{{coord|50.97220|N|1.94156|W|region:GB_source:enwiki-osgb36(SU042192)|display=title}}<!-- Note: WGS84 lat/long, converted from OSGB36 grid ref -->

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2018}} [[File:C. J. Cherryh 1994 (recrop).jpg|thumb|right|225px|[[C. J. Cherryh]] at Norcon 12, [[Oslo]], Norway, August 1994.]]
American writer [[C. J. Cherryh]]{{`s}} career began with publication of her first books in 1976, ''[[Gate of Ivrel]]'' and ''[[Brothers of Earth]]''. She has been a prolific [[science fiction]] and [[fantasy]] author since then, publishing over 80 novels, short-story compilations, with continuing production as her [[blog]] attests.<ref name="che-progress">{{cite web | author=Cherryh, C. J. |authorlink=C. J. Cherryh | year= | title=Progress Report | url=http://www.cherryh.com/www/progress.htm | work=Cherryh.com | accessdate=February 9, 2009}}</ref> Ms. Cherryh has received the [[Hugo Award|Hugo]] and [[Locus (magazine)|Locus]] Awards for some of her novels.
Her novels are divided into various spheres, focusing mostly around the [[Alliance-Union universe]], the [[Foreigner universe]] and her fantasy novels.
==The Alliance-Union universe== {{Main article|Alliance-Union universe}} The Alliance-Union universe is a science fiction [[future history]] series, in which the development of political entities and cultures occurs over a long time period. Major characters in one work may be referenced or appear briefly in another.
===The Company Wars===
According to the author, the novels in this universe, except ''Heavy Time'' and ''Hellburner'' (which were subsequently re-published in one volume as ''[[Devil to the Belt]]''), can be read in any order.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cherryh.com/www/univer.htm#Alliance-Union| title=C.J. Cherryh's webpage|accessdate=February 6, 2009}}</ref>
* ''[[Downbelow Station]]'' (1981) – Hugo winner, Locus SF Award nominee, 1982<ref name="WWE-1982">{{cite web|url=https://www.worldswithoutend.com/books_year_index.asp?year=1982|title=Science Fiction & Fantasy Books by Award: 1982 Award Winners & Nominees|work=Worlds Without End|accessdate=March 25, 2009}}</ref> * ''[[Merchanter's Luck]]'' (1982) ** also published in the ''Alliance Space'' (2008) omnibus * ''[[Rimrunners]]'' (1989) – Locus SF Award nominee, 1990<ref name="WWE-1990">{{cite web|url=https://www.worldswithoutend.com/books_year_index.asp?year=1990|title=Science Fiction & Fantasy Books by Award: 1990 Award Winners & Nominees|work=Worlds Without End|accessdate=March 25, 2009}}</ref> * ''[[Devil to the Belt|Heavy Time]]'' (1991) * ''[[Devil to the Belt|Hellburner]]'' (1992) ** ''[[Devil to the Belt]]'' (2000) – single-volume edition of the above two books * ''[[Tripoint (novel)|Tripoint]]'' (1994) * ''[[Finity's End]]'' (1997) – Locus SF Award nominee, 1998<ref name="WWE-1998">{{cite web|url=https://www.worldswithoutend.com/books_year_index.asp?year=1998|title=Science Fiction & Fantasy Books by Award: 1998 Award Winners & Nominees|work=Worlds Without End|accessdate=March 25, 2009}}</ref> * ''Alliance Rising'' (forthcoming, January 2019) – credited to C. J. Cherryh and [[Jane Fancher]]
===The Era of Rapprochement=== * ''[[Serpent's Reach]]'' (1980) ** also published in ''The Deep Beyond'' (2005) omnibus * ''[[Forty Thousand in Gehenna]]'' (1983) ** also published in the ''Alliance Space'' (2008) omnibus * "[[The Scapegoat (Cherryh novel)|The Scapegoat]]" (1985) – novella * ''[[Cyteen]]'' (1988) – Hugo and Locus SF Award winner, British Science Fiction Award nominee, 1989<ref name="WWE-1989">{{cite web|url=https://www.worldswithoutend.com/books_year_index.asp?year=1989|title=Science Fiction & Fantasy Books by Award: 1989 Award Winners & Nominees|work=Worlds Without End|accessdate=March 25, 2009}}</ref> ** also published in a 3-volume edition as ''The Betrayal'', ''The Rebirth'' and ''The Vindication'', about which Cherryh has written, "There was a paperbound publication that split the novel into three parts, but this has ended: the current and, by my wishes, all future publications, will have Cyteen as one unified book."<ref name="che-cytri">{{cite web | author=Cherryh, C. J. | authorlink=C. J. Cherryh | title=Universes of C. J. Cherryh – Alliance-Union | url=http://www.cherryh.com/www/univer.htm#Alliance/Union | work=Cherryh.com | accessdate=August 15, 2006}}</ref> * ''[[Regenesis (novel)|Regenesis]]'' (2009)
===The Chanur novels=== {{Main article|The Chanur novels}} * ''The Pride of Chanur'' (1981) – Hugo and Locus SF Award nominee, 1983<ref name="WWE-1983">{{cite web|url=https://www.worldswithoutend.com/books_year_index.asp?year=1983|title=Science Fiction & Fantasy Books by Award: 1983 Award Winners & Nominees|work=Worlds Without End|accessdate=March 25, 2009}}</ref> * ''Chanur's Venture'' (1984) – Locus SF Award nominee, 1985<ref name="WWE-1985">{{cite web|url=https://www.worldswithoutend.com/books_year_index.asp?year=1985|title=Science Fiction & Fantasy Books by Award: 1985 Award Winners & Nominees|work=Worlds Without End|accessdate=March 25, 2009}}</ref> * ''The Kif Strike Back'' (1985) ** ''The Chanur Saga'' (2000) – single-volume edition of the above three books * ''Chanur's Homecoming'' (1986) * ''Chanur's Legacy'' (1992) ** ''Chanur's Endgame'' (2007) – single-volume edition of the above two books
===The Mri Wars=== {{Main article|Faded Sun Trilogy}} * ''The Faded Sun: Kesrith'' (1978) – Hugo and Locus SF Award nominee, 1979;<ref name="WWE-1979">{{cite web|url=https://www.worldswithoutend.com/books_year_index.asp?year=1979|title=Science Fiction & Fantasy Books by Award: 1979 Award Winners & Nominees|work=Worlds Without End|accessdate=March 25, 2009}}</ref> Nebula Award nominee, 1978 <ref name="WWE-1978">{{cite web|url=https://www.worldswithoutend.com/books_year_index.asp?year=1978|title=Science Fiction & Fantasy Books by Award: 1978 Award Winners & Nominees|work=Worlds Without End|accessdate=March 25, 2009}}</ref> * ''The Faded Sun: Shon'Jir'' (1978) * ''The Faded Sun: Kutath'' (1979) ** ''The Faded Sun Trilogy'' (UK, 1987 and US, 2000) – single-volume edition of the above three books
===Merovingen Nights (Mri Wars Period)=== {{Main article|Merovingen Nights}} * ''Angel with the Sword'' (1985) ** ''Merovingen Nights'' – [[shared universe|shared world]] series of anthologies (see "As Editor" below)
===The Age of Exploration=== These novels share a common theme, but are unrelated to each other and can be read in any order. * ''[[Alternate Realities (Cherryh)#Port Eternity|Port Eternity]]'' (1982) ** also published in the ''[[Alternate Realities (Cherryh)|Alternate realities]]'' (2000) omnibus * ''[[Alternate Realities (Cherryh)#Voyager in Night|Voyager in Night]]'' (1984) – Philip K. Dick Award nominee, 1984 <ref name="WWE-1984">{{cite web|url=https://www.worldswithoutend.com/books_year_index.asp?year=1984|title=Science Fiction & Fantasy Books by Award: 1984 Award Winners & Nominees|work=Worlds Without End|accessdate=April 29, 2009}}</ref> ** also published in the ''[[Alternate Realities (Cherryh)|Alternate realities]]'' (2000) omnibus * ''[[Cuckoo's Egg]]'' (1985) – Hugo Award nominee, 1986<ref name="WWE-1986">{{cite web|url=https://www.worldswithoutend.com/books_year_index.asp?year=1986|title=Science Fiction & Fantasy Books by Award: 1986 Award Winners & Nominees|work=Worlds Without End|accessdate=March 25, 2009}}</ref> ** also published in ''The Deep Beyond'' (2005) omnibus
===The Hanan Rebellion=== * ''[[Brothers of Earth]]'' (1976) * ''[[Hunter of Worlds]]'' (1977) ** ''At the Edge of Space'' (2003) – single-volume edition of the above two books
===The Morgaine Cycle=== {{Main article|The Morgaine Stories}} * ''[[Gate of Ivrel]]'' (1976) * ''[[Well of Shiuan]]'' (1978) * ''[[Fires of Azeroth]]'' (1979) ** Above three collected in the following editions: ***''The Book of Morgaine'' (1979) ***''The Chronicles of Morgaine'' (1989) ***''The Morgaine Saga'' (2000) * ''[[Exile's Gate]]'' (1988)
===Miscellaneous=== * ''[[Alternate Realities (Cherryh)#Wave Without a Shore|Wave Without a Shore]]'' (1981) ** also published in the ''[[Alternate Realities (Cherryh)|Alternate realities]]'' (2000) omnibus
==The Foreigner universe== {{Main article|Foreigner universe}} *Trilogy arc 1 ** ''Foreigner'' (1994) – Locus SF Award nominee, 1995<ref name="WWE-1995">{{cite web|url=https://www.worldswithoutend.com/books_year_index.asp?year=1995|title=Science Fiction & Fantasy Books by Award: 1995 Award Winners & Nominees|work=Worlds Without End|accessdate=March 25, 2009}}</ref> ** ''Invader'' (1995) – Locus SF Award nominee, 1996<ref name="WWE-1996">{{cite web|url=https://www.worldswithoutend.com/books_year_index.asp?year=1996|title=Science Fiction & Fantasy Books by Award: 1996 Award Winners & Nominees|work=Worlds Without End|accessdate=March 25, 2009}}</ref> ** ''Inheritor'' (1996) *Trilogy arc 2 ** ''Precursor'' (1999) ** ''Defender'' (2001) – Locus SF Award nominee, 2002<ref name="WWE-2002">{{cite web|url=https://www.worldswithoutend.com/books_year_index.asp?year=2002|title=Science Fiction & Fantasy Books by Award: 2002 Award Winners & Nominees|work=Worlds Without End|accessdate=March 25, 2009}}</ref> ** ''Explorer'' (2003) *Trilogy arc 3 ** ''Destroyer'' (2005) ** ''Pretender'' (2006) ** ''Deliverer'' (2007) *Trilogy arc 4 ** ''Conspirator'' (2009) ** ''Deceiver'' (2010) ** ''Betrayer'' (2011) *Trilogy arc 5 ** ''Intruder'' (2012) ** ''Protector'' (2013) ** ''Peacemaker'' (2014) *Trilogy arc 6 ** ''Tracker'' (2015) ** ''Visitor'' (2016) – Locus SF Award nominee, 2017<ref name="WWE-2017">{{cite web|url=https://www.worldswithoutend.com/books_year_index.asp?year=2017|title=Science Fiction & Fantasy Books by Award: 2017 Award Winners & Nominees|work=Worlds Without End|accessdate=January 31, 2018}}</ref> ** ''Convergence'' (2017) *Trilogy arc 7 ** ''Emergence'' (2018) ** ''Resurgence'' (in progress)
==Other science fiction== ===Finisterre universe=== {{Main article|Finisterre universe}} * ''[[Rider at the Gate]]'' (1995) * ''[[Cloud's Rider]]'' (1996)
===Gene Wars=== {{Main article|The Gene Wars universe}} * ''[[Hammerfall (novel)|Hammerfall]]'' (2001) – Campbell Award nominee, 2002<ref name="WWE-2002"/> * ''[[Forge of Heaven]]'' (2004)
===Miscellaneous=== * "[[Cassandra (short story)|Cassandra]]" (1978) – short story, Hugo Award winner, 1979<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.isfdb.org/cgi-bin/title.cgi?49957|title=Bibliography: Cassandra|publisher=[[Internet Speculative Fiction Database]]|accessdate=August 8, 2014}}</ref> * ''[[Hestia (novel)|Hestia]]'' (1979)
==Fantasy works==
===The Fortress series=== {{Main article|The Fortress Series}} * ''Fortress in the Eye of Time'' (1995) – Locus Fantasy Award nominee, 1996<ref name="WWE-1996"/> * ''Fortress of Eagles'' (1998) – Locus Fantasy Award nominee, 1999<ref name="WWE-1999">{{cite web|url=https://www.worldswithoutend.com/books_year_index.asp?year=1989|title=Science Fiction & Fantasy Books by Award: 1999 Award Winners & Nominees|work=Worlds Without End|accessdate=November 2, 2015}}</ref> * ''Fortress of Owls'' (1999) – Locus Fantasy Award nominee, 2000<ref name="WWE-2000">{{cite web|url=https://www.worldswithoutend.com/books_year_index.asp?year=2000|title=Science Fiction & Fantasy Books by Award: 2000 Award Winners & Nominees|work=Worlds Without End|accessdate=March 25, 2009}}</ref> * ''Fortress of Dragons'' (2000) * ''Fortress of Ice'' (2006)
===Ealdwood=== {{Main article|Ealdwood Stories}} * "[[Ealdwood]]" (1981 novella) * ''[[The Dreamstone (novel)|The Dreamstone]]'' (1983 novel) – includes material from Cherryh's short story "The Dreamstone" (1979) and the novella "Ealdwood" * ''[[The Tree of Swords and Jewels]]'' (1983 novel) * ''Arafel's Saga'' (1983) – single-volume edition of ''The Dreamstone'' (1983) and ''The Tree of Swords and Jewels'' (1983) * ''Ealdwood'' (1991) – single-volume edition of ''The Dreamstone'' (1983) and ''The Tree of Swords and Jewels'' (1983) with revisions and a new ending * ''The Dreaming Tree'' (1997) – single-volume edition of ''The Dreamstone'' (1983) and ''The Tree of Swords and Jewels'' (1983) with the ''Ealdwood'' (1991) revisions
===The Russian stories=== {{Main article|The Russian Stories (C. J. Cherryh)|l1=The Russian Stories}} * ''[[Rusalka (book)|Rusalka]]'' (1989) – Locus Fantasy Award nominee, 1990<ref name="WWE-1990"/> ** ''Rusalka'' (2010) – revised ebook edition * ''[[Chernevog]]'' (1990) ** ''Chernevog'' (2012) – revised ebook edition, credited to C. J. Cherryh and [[Jane Fancher]] * ''[[Yvgenie]]'' (1991) ** ''Yvgenie'' (2012) – revised ebook edition
===''Heroes in Hell''=== {{Main article|Heroes in Hell}} * ''[[The Gates of Hell (1986 novel)|The Gates of Hell]]'' (1986), novel with [[Janet Morris]] * ''[[Kings in Hell]]'' (1986), novel with Janet Morris * ''[[Legions of Hell]]'' (1987)
===Miscellaneous fantasy=== * "[[The Brothers (novella)|The Brothers]]" (1986) – novella * ''[[The Paladin]]'' (1988) – Locus Fantasy Award nominee, 1989<ref name="WWE-1989"/> * ''[[The Goblin Mirror]]'' (1992) * ''[[Faery in Shadow]]'' (1993) ** ''[[Faery in Shadow#Faery Moon|Faery Moon]]'' (2009) – revised ebook edition of ''Faery in Shadow'', plus its prequel, "The Brothers" * ''[[Lois & Clark: A Superman Novel]]'' (1996)
==Collections==
===Omnibuses=== *''The Book of Morgaine'' (1979) – ''[[Gate of Ivrel]]'' (1976), ''[[Well of Shiuan]]'' (1978) and ''[[Fires of Azeroth]]'' (1979) *''[[Ealdwood Stories|Arafel's Saga]]'' (1983) – ''The Dreamstone'' (1983) and ''The Tree of Swords and Jewels'' (1983) *''The Chronicles of Morgaine'' (1989) – ''[[Gate of Ivrel]]'' (1976), ''[[Well of Shiuan]]'' (1978) and ''[[Fires of Azeroth]]'' (1979) *''[[Ealdwood Stories|Ealdwood]]'' (1991) – ''[[The Dreamstone (novel)|The Dreamstone]]'' (1983) and ''[[The Tree of Swords and Jewels]]'' (1983) with revisions and a new ending *''[[Ealdwood Stories|The Dreaming Tree]]'' (1997) – ''[[The Dreamstone (novel)|The Dreamstone]]'' (1983) and ''[[The Tree of Swords and Jewels]]'' (1983) with revisions and a new ending *''The Morgaine Saga'' (2000) – ''[[Gate of Ivrel]]'' (1976), ''[[Well of Shiuan]]'' (1978) and ''[[Fires of Azeroth]]'' (1979) *''[[Faded Sun Trilogy|The Faded Sun Trilogy]]'' (2000) – ''Kesrith'' (1978), ''Shon'Jir'' (1978) and ''Kutath'' (1979) *''[[The Chanur novels|The Chanur Saga]]'' (2000) – ''The Pride of Chanur'' (1981), ''Chanur's Venture'' (1984) and ''The Kif Strike Back'' (1985) *''[[Devil to the Belt]]'' (2000) – ''Heavy Time'' (1991) and ''Hellburner'' (1992) *''[[Alternate Realities (Cherryh)|Alternate Realities]]'' (2000) – ''Wave Without a Shore'' (1981), ''Port Eternity'' (1982) and ''Voyager in Night'' (1984) *''At the Edge of Space'' (2003) – ''[[Brothers of Earth]]'' (1976) and ''[[Hunter of Worlds]]'' (1977) *''The Deep Beyond'' (2005) – ''[[Serpent's Reach]]'' (1980) and ''[[Cuckoo's Egg]]'' (1985) *''[[The Chanur novels|Chanur's Endgame]]'' (2007) – ''Chanur's Homecoming'' (1986) and ''Chanur's Legacy'' (1992) *''Alliance Space'' (2008) – ''[[Merchanter's Luck]]'' (1982) and ''[[Forty Thousand in Gehenna]]'' (1983)
===Short fiction=== *''[[The Collected Short Fiction of C. J. Cherryh|Sunfall]]'' (1981) – short stories and novelettes *''[[The Collected Short Fiction of C. J. Cherryh|Visible Light]]'' (1986) – short stories, novelettes and novellas *''[[Glass and Amber]]'' (1987) – short stories and essays *''[[The Collected Short Fiction of C. J. Cherryh]]'' (2004) – short stories, novelettes and novellas, including those in ''Sunfall'', ''Visible Light''
=== Anthologies === * Altered States: a cyberpunk sci-fi anthology (2014) – "Mech" (1992)
==Other works==
===As editor=== The ''[[Merovingen Nights]]'' shared-world anthologies are set on the world of Merovin in Cherryh's Alliance-Union universe. They are collections of interrelated short stories written by Cherryh and others. Cherryh's novel ''Angel with the Sword'' precedes book #1 in this series. *''Festival Moon'' (1987) – Merovingen Nights #1 *''Fever Season'' (1987) – Merovingen Nights #2 *''Troubled Waters'' (1988) – Merovingen Nights #3 *''Smuggler's Gold'' (1988) – Merovingen Nights #4 *''Divine Right'' (1989) – Merovingen Nights #5 *''Flood Tide'' (1990) – Merovingen Nights #6 *''Endgame'' (1991) – Merovingen Nights #7
===As translator=== From [[French language|French]] to [[English language|English]]: *''The Green Gods'' (1980), by [[Nathalie Henneberg|N. C. Henneberg]] (Nathalie and Charles Henneberg) *''Stellar Crusade'' (1980), by [[Pierre Barbet (writer)|Pierre Barbet]] *''The Book of Shai'' (1982), by Daniel Walther *''Shai's Destiny'' (1985), by Daniel Walther
===Other credits=== {{Main article|The Sword of Knowledge}} Cherryh did not write the three novels in the ''Sword of Knowledge'' series, but received co-author's credit because she penned a foreword to each. The publisher removed Cherryh's introductions from most or all editions of these works. * ''A Dirge for Sabis'' (1989), by Cherryh and [[Leslie Fish]] * ''Wizard Spawn'' (1989), by Cherryh and [[Nancy Asire]] * ''Reap the Whirlwind'' (1989), by Cherryh and [[Mercedes Lackey]] **''The Sword of Knowledge'' (1995) – compilation of the three titles in a single volume
===Scholarship=== Works about C. J. Cherryh written by others. * ''[[The Cherryh Odyssey]]'' (2004), by Edward Carmien – a collection of essays by academics, critics and authors about C. J. Cherryh
==References== {{reflist|30em}}

Cherryh: Bio and Bibliography] at the author's official site. *[http://www.cherryh.com/www/univer.htm Universes of C. J. Cherryh] at the author's official site. *{{isfdb_name|id=C._J._Cherryh|name=C. J. Cherryh}}. *[https://www.fantasticfiction.com/c/c-j-cherryh/ C. J. Cherryh] at Fantastic Fiction. *{{OL author|OL7046811A}} *[http://scifan.com/writers/cc/CherryhCJ.asp C. J. Cherryh bibliography] at SciFan. *[https://www.perrochon.com/cherryh/ref/cjbiblio.html Complete Bibliography of C. J. Cherryh] (through 1995) at Meetpoint.
{{C. J. Cherryh}}

page.title: Classification schemes for indigenous languages of the Americas

revision.text:
This article is a list of different language classification proposals developed for [[indigenous languages of the Americas]]. The article is divided into North, Central, and South America sections; however, the classifications do not always neatly correspond to these continent divisions. [[Image:Langs N.Amer.png|thumb|300px|Pre-contact distribution of North American language families north of Mexico]] [[Image:Map of the languages of Mexico.png|300px|thumb|The indigenous languages of Mexico that have more than 100,000 speakers]] [[File:Chibcha lang.png|thumb|right|300px|The native [[Chibcha language]] group.]] ''(See: '''[[Indigenous languages of the Americas]]''' for the main article about these languages.)'' ==North America== ===Gallatin (1836)=== An early attempt at North American language classification was attempted by [[Albert Gallatin|A. A. Albert Gallatin]] published in 1826, 1836, and 1848. Gallatin's classifications are missing several languages which are later recorded in the classifications by [[Daniel Garrison Brinton|Daniel G. Brinton]] and [[John Wesley Powell]]. (Gallatin supported the assimilation of indigenous peoples to Euro-American culture.) : (Current terminology is indicated parenthetically in ''italics''.) '''Families''' # Algonkin-Lenape '' (=Algonquian)'' # Athapascas '' (=Athabaskan)'' # Catawban '' (=Catawba + Woccons)'' # Eskimaux '' (=Eskimoan)'' # Iroquois '' (=Northern Iroquoian)'' # Cherokees '' (=Southern Iroquoian)'' # Muskogee '' (=Eastern Muskogean)'' # Chahtas '' (=Western Muskogean)'' # Sioux '' (=Siouan)'' '''Languages''' {| | valign="top" width="65%" | # Adaize '' (=Adai)'' # Attacapas '' (=Atakapa)'' # Salmon River '' (=Bella Coola)'' # Black Feet '' (=Blackfoot)'' # Pawnees '' (=Northern Caddoan)'' # Caddoes '' (=Southern Caddoan)'' # Chinooks '' (=Chinookan)'' # Chetimachas '' (=Chitimacha)'' # Fall Indians '' (=Gros Ventre)'' # Queen Charlotte's Island '' (=Haida)'' | valign="top" | 11. Straits of Fuca '' (=Makah)''
12. Natches '' (=Natchez)''
13. Wakash '' (=Nootka)''
14. Salish '' (=Salishan)''
15. Shoshonees '' (=Shoshone)''
16. Atnahs '' (=Shuswap)''
17. Kinai '' (=Tanaina)''
18. Koulischen '' (=Tlingit)''
19. Utchees '' (=Yuchi)'' |} ===Gallatin (1848)=== '''Families''' # Algonquian languages # Athabaskan languages # Catawban languages # Eskimoan languages # Iroquoian languages (Northern) # Iroquoian languages (Southern) # Muskogean languages # Siouan languages '''Languages''' {| | valign="top" width="55%" |   1. Adai
  2. Alsean
  3. Apache
  4. Arapaho
  5. Atakapa
  6. Caddoan, Northern
  7. Caddoan, Southern
  8. Cayuse-Molala
  9. Chinookan
10. Chitimacha
11. Comanche
12. Haida
13. Kalapuyan
14. Kiowa
15. Klamath
16. Koasati-Alabama
17. Kootenai
| valign="top" | 18. Kutchin
19. Maricopa (Yuman)
20. Natchez
21. Palaihnihan
22. Plains Apache
23. Sahaptian
24. Salishan
25. Shasta
26. Shoshone
27. Tanaina
28. Tlingit
29. Tsimshian
30. Ute
31. Wakashan, Southern
32. Wichita
33. Yuchi
|} ===Powell's (1892) "Fifty-eight"=== [[John Wesley Powell]], an explorer who served as director of the [[Bureau of American Ethnology]], published a classification of 58 "[[Language family#Subdivision|stocks]]" that is the "cornerstone" of genetic classifications in North America. Powell's classification was influenced by Gallatin to a large extent. John Wesley Powell was in a race with [[Daniel G. Brinton]] to publish the first comprehensive classification of North America languages (although Brinton's classification also covered South and Central America). As a result of this competition, Brinton was not allowed access to the linguistic data collected by Powell's fieldworkers. : ''(More current names are indicated parenthetically.)'' {| style="font-size: 95%;" | valign="top" width="34%" |   1. Adaizan
  2. Algonquian
  3. Athapascan
  4. Attacapan '' (=Atakapa)''
  5. Beothukan '' (=Beothuk)''
  6. Caddoan
  7. Chimakuan
  8. Chimarikan '' (=Chimariko)''
  9. Chimmesyan '' (=Tsimshian)''
10. Chinookan
11. Chitimachan '' (=Chitimacha)''
12. Chumashan
13. Coahuiltecan
14. Copehan '' (=Wintuan)''
15. Costanoan
16. Eskimauan '' (=Eskimoan)''
17. Esselenian '' (=Esselen)''
18. Iroquoian
19. Kalapooian '' (=Kalapuyan)''
20. Karankawan '' (=Karankawa)''
| valign="top" width="34%" | 21. Keresan
22. Kiowan '' (=Kiowa)''
23. Kitunahan '' (=Kutenai)''
24. Koluschan '' (=Tlingit)''
25. Kulanapan '' (=Pomoan)''
26. Kusan '' (=Coosan)''
27. Lutuamian '' (=Klamath-Modoc)''
28. Mariposan '' (=Yokutsan)''
29. Moquelumnan '' (=Miwokan)''
30. Muskhogean '' (=Muskogean)''

|} ===Sapir (1929): Encyclopædia Britannica=== Below is [[Edward Sapir]]'s (1929) famous ''Encyclopædia Britannica'' classification. Note that Sapir's classification was controversial at the time and it additionally was an original proposal (unusual for general encyclopedias). Sapir was part of a "[[lumper (taxonomy)|lumper]]" movement in Native American language classification. Sapir himself writes of his classification: "A more far-reaching scheme than Powell's [1891 classification], suggestive but not demonstrable in all its features at the present time" (Sapir 1929: 139). Sapir's classifies all the languages in North America into only 6 families: Eskimo–Aleut, Algonkin–Wakashan, Nadene, Penutian, Hokan–Siouan, and Aztec–Tanoan. Sapir's classification (or something derivative) is still commonly used in general languages-of-the-world type surveys. (Note that the question marks that appear in Sapir's list below are present in the original article.) : "Proposed Classification of American Indian Languages North of Mexico (and Certain Languages of Mexico and Central America)" {| style="font-size: 95%;" | valign="top" width="40%" | '''I. ''[[Eskimo–Aleut]]''''' '''II. ''[[Algonkin–Wakashan]]''''' : 1. ''[[Algonkin–Ritwan]]'' :: (1) [[Algonquian languages|Algonkin]] :: (2) [[Beothuk language|Beothuk]] (?) :: (3) Ritwan ::: (a) [[Wiyot language|Wiyot]] ::: (b) [[Yurok language|Yurok]] : 2. ''[[Kutenai language|Kootenay]]'' : 3. ''[[Mosan languages|Mosan]] (Wakashan–Salish)'' :: (1) [[Wakashan]] (Kwakiutl–Nootka) :: (2) [[Chimakuan]] :: (3) [[Salishan languages|Salish]] '''III. ''[[Nadene]]''''' : 1. ''[[Haida language|Haida]]'' : 2. ''Continental Nadene'' :: (1) [[Tlingit language|Tlingit]] :: (2) [[Athabaskan]] '''IV. ''[[Penutian]]''''' : 1. ''Californian Penutian'' :: (1) [[Miwok-Costanoan]] :: (2) [[Yokutsan languages|Yokuts]] :: (3) [[Maiduan languages|Maidu]] :: (4) [[Wintuan languages|Wintun]] : 2. ''Oregon Penutian'' :: (1) [[Takelma language|Takelma]] :: (2) Coast Oregon Penutian ::: (a) [[Coosan languages|Coos]] ::: (b) [[Siuslaw language|Siuslaw]] ::: (c) [[Yakonan language|Yakonan]] :: (3) [[Kalapuyan languages|Kalapuya]] : 3. ''[[Chinookan languages|Chinook]]'' : 4. ''[[Tsimshianic languages|Tsimshian]]'' : 5. ''[[Plateau Penutian]]'' :: (1) [[Sahaptin language|Sahaptin]] :: (2) [[Waiilatpuan language|Waiilatpuan]] (Molala–Cayuse) :: (3) [[Klamath language|Lutuami]] (Klamath-Modoc) : 6. ''Mexican Penutian'' :: (1) [[Mixe–Zoque]] :: (2) [[Huave language|Huave]] | valign="top" width="40%" | '''V. ''Hokan–Siouan''''' : 1. ''Hokan–Coahuiltecan'' :: A. [[Hokan languages|Hokan]] ::: (1) Northern Hokan :::: (a) Karok, Chimariko, Shasta–Achomawl :::: (b) Yana :::: (c) Pomo ::: (2) Washo ::: (3) Esselen–Yuman :::: (a) Esselen :::: (b) Yuman ::: (4) Salinan–Seri :::: (a) Salinan :::: (b) Chumash :::: (c) Seri ::: (5) Tequistlatecan (Chontal) :: B. Subtiaba–Tlappanec :: C. Coahuiltecan ::: (1) Tonkawa ::: (2) Coahuilteco :::: (a) Coahuilteco proper :::: (b) Cotoname :::: (c) Comecrudo ::: (3) Karankawa : 2. ''Yuki'' : 3. ''Keres'' : 4. ''Tunican''{{anchor|Tunican}} :: (1) [[Tunica language|Tunica]]–[[Atakapa language|Atakapa]] :: (2) [[Chitimacha language|Chitimacha]] : 5. ''Iroquois'' :: (1) Iroquoian :: (2) Caddoan : 6. ''Eastern group'' :: (1) Siouan–Yuchi ::: (a) Siouan ::: (b) Yuchi :: (2) Natchez–Muskogian ::: (a) Natchez ::: (b) Muskogian ::: (c) Timucua (?) | valign="top" width="40%" | '''VI. ''Aztec–Tanoan''''' : 1. ''[[Uto-Aztekan]]'' :: (1) Nahuatl :: (2) Piman :: (3) Shoshonean : 2. ''Tanoan–Kiowa'' :: (1) Tanoan :: (2) Kiowa : 3. ''Zuñi (?)'' |} ===Voegelin & Voegelin (1965): The "Consensus" of 1964=== [[Image:Early Localization Native Americans USA.jpg|thumb|300px]] [[Image:Early Indian Languages Alaska.jpg|thumb]] The Voegelin & Voegelin (1965) classification was the result of a conference of Americanist linguists held at Indiana University in 1964. This classification identifies 16 main genetic units. {| style="font-size: 95%;" cellpadding="7" | valign="top" width="50%" | # '''American Arctic-[[Paleosiberian]]''' phylum #* [[Eskimo–Aleut]] #* [[Chukchi–Kamchatkan]] # '''[[Na-Dene]]''' phylum #* [[Athapascan]] #* [[Tlingit language|Tlingit]] #* [[Haida language|Haida]] # '''Macro-Algonquian''' phylum #* [[Algonquian languages|Algonquian]] #* [[Yurok language|Yurok]] #* [[Wiyot language|Wiyot]] #* [[Muskogean]] #* [[Natchez language|Natchez]] #* [[Atakapa language|Atakapa]] #* [[Chitimacha language|Chitimacha]] #* [[Tunica language|Tunica]] #* [[Tonkawa language|Tonkawa]] # '''[[Macro-Siouan]]''' phylum #* [[Siouan]] #* [[Catawba language|Catawba]] #* [[Caddoan]] #* [[Yuchi language|Yuchi]] # '''[[Hokan languages|Hokan]]''' phylum #* [[Yuman languages|Yuman]] #* [[Seri language|Seri]] #* [[Pomoan languages|Pomoan]] #* [[Palaihnihan]] #* [[Shastan languages|Shastan]] #* [[Yana language|Yanan]] #* [[Chimariko language|Chimariko]] #* [[Washo language|Washo]] #* [[Salinan language|Salinan]] #* [[Karuk language|Karok]] #* [[Chumashan]] #* [[Comecrudan]] #* [[Coahuiltecan languages|Coahuiltecan]] #* [[Esselen]] #* [[Jicaquean languages|Jicaque]] #* [[Tlapanecan]] #* [[Tequistlatecan]] | valign="top" width="60%" |  6. '''[[Penutian]]''' phylum * [[Yokutsan|Yokuts]] * [[Maiduan|Maidu]] * [[Wintuan|Wintun]] * [[Miwok–Costanoan]] * [[Klamath language|Klamath]]–[[Modoc language|Modoc]] * [[Sahaptin–Nez Perce]] * [[Cayuse language|Cayuse]] * [[Molale]] * [[Coosan|Coos]] * [[Yakonan]] * [[Takelma language|Takelma]] * [[Kalapuyan|Kalapuya]] * [[Chinookan language|Chinookan]] * [[Tsimshianic|Tsimshian]] * [[Zuni language|Zuni]] * [[Mixe–Zoque]] * [[Mayan languages|Mayan]] * [[Chipaya–Uru]] * [[Totonacan]] * [[Huave language|Huave]]  7. '''[[Aztec–Tanoan]]''' phylum * [[Kiowa–Tanoan]] * [[Uto-Aztecan]]  8. '''[[Keresan languages|Keres]]'''
 9. '''[[Yuki language|Yuki]]'''
10. '''[[Beothuk language|Beothuk]]'''

16. '''[[Timucua language|Timucua]]'''
|} Chumashan, Comecrudan, and Coahuiltecan included in Hokan with "reservations". Esselen is included in Hokan with "strong reservations". Tsimshian and Zuni are included in Penutian with reservations. ===Campbell & Mithun (1979): The "Black Book"=== Campbell & Mithun's 1979 is a more conservative classification where they insist on more rigorous demonstration of genetic relationship before grouping. Thus, many of the speculative phyla of previous authors are "split". ===Goddard (1996), Campbell (1997), Mithun (1999)=== (preliminary) '''Families''' # [[Algic languages|Algic]] ## Algonquian ## Wiyot (>Ritwan?) ## Yurok (>Ritwan?) # [[Na-Dene languages|Na-Dene]] ## Eyak-Athabaskan ### Eyak ### Athabaskan ## Tlingit # Caddoan (>Macro-Siouan?) # Chimakuan # Chinookan (> Penutian?) # Chumashan [chúmash] # [[Comecrudan languages|Comecrudan]] # Coosan [kus] (> Coast Penutian?) # Eskimo–Aleut ## Eskimoan ## Aleut = Unangan # Iroquoian # Kalapuyan [kalapúyan] # [[Kiowa–Tanoan languages|Kiowa–Tanoan]] # Maiduan # Muskogean # Palaihnihan (Achumawi–Atsugewi) # Pomoan # Sahaptian # Salishan # Shastan # [[Siouan–Catawban languages|Siouan–Catawban]] ## [[Western Siouan languages|Siouan]] ## [[Catawban languages|Catawban]] # Tsimshianic # [[Utian languages|Utian]] ## Miwok ## Costanoan # [[Utaztecan languages|Utaztecan]] ## Numic = Plateau ## Tübatulabal = Kern ## Takic = Southern California ## Hopi = Pueblo ## Tepiman = Pimic ## Taracahitic ## Tubar ## Corachol ## Aztecan # Wakashan ## Kwakiutlan ## Nootkan # Wintuan (>Coast Penutian?) # Yokutsan # [[Yuman–Cochimi languages|Yuman–Cochimi]] ## Yuman ## Cochimi '''Isolates''' # Adai # Alsea [alsi] (> Coast Penutian?) # Atakapa (>Tunican?) # Beothuk (unclassifiable?) # Cayuse # Chimariko # Chititmacha (>Tunican?) # Coahuilteco # Cotoname = Carrizo de Camargo # Esselen # Haida # Karankawa # Karuk # Keres # Klamath-Modoc # Kootenai # Molala # Natchez # Salinan # Siuslaw (>Coast Penutian?) # Takelma # Timucua # Tonkawa # Tunica (>Tunican?) # Wappo (>Yuki–Wappo) # Washo # Yana # Yuchi (>Siouan) # Yuki (>Yuki–Wappo) # Zuni '''Stocks''' * [[Yuki–Wappo languages|Yuki–Wappo]], supported by Elmendorf (1981, 1997) Penutian outside Mexico considered probably by many * [[Penutian languages|Penutian]] # Tsimshianic # Chinookan # Takelma # Kalapuya (not close to Takelma: Tarpent & Kendall 1998) # Maidun # Oregon Coast-Wintu (Whistler 1977, Golla 1997) ## Alsea ## Coosan ## Siuslaw ## Wintuan # Plateau ## Sahaptian ## Klamath ## Molala ## Cayuse ? (poor data) # [[Yok-Utian languages|Yok-Utian]] ? ## Yokuts ## Utian Siouan–Yuchi "probable"; Macro-Siouan likely * [[Macro-Siouan languages|Macro-Siouan]] # Iroquoian–Caddoan ## Iroquoian ## Caddoan # [[Siouan–Yuchi languages|Siouan–Yuchi]] ## Siouan–Catawban ## Yuchi Natchez–Muskogean most likely of the Gulf hypothesis * [[Natchez–Muskogean languages|Natchez–Muskogean]] # Natchez # Muskogean Hokan: most promising proposals * [[Hokan languages|Hokan]] # Karuk # Chimariko # Shastan # Palaihnihan # Yana # Washo # Pomoan # Esselen # Salinan # Yuman–Cochimi # Seri "Unlikely" to be Hokan: :Chumashan :Tonkawa :Karankawa [[Subtiaba–Tlapanec languages|Subtiaba–Tlapanec]] is likely part of Otomanguean (Rensch 1977, Oltrogge 1977). [[Aztec–Tanoan languages|Aztec–Tanoan]] is "undemonstrated"; [[Mosan languages|Mosan]] is a Sprachbund. ==Mesoamerica== (Consensus conservative classification) '''Families''' * Uto-Aztecan (Other branches outside Mesoamerica. See North America) :# Corachol (Cora–Huichol) :# Aztecan (Nahua–Pochutec) * Totonac–Tepehua * Otomanguean :# Otopamean :# Popolocan–Mazatecan :# Subtiaba–Tlapanec :# Amuzgo :# Mixtecan :# Chatino–Zapotec :# Chinantec :# Chiapanec–Mangue (extinct) * Tequistlatec-Jicaque * Mixe–Zoque * Mayan * Misumalpan (Outside Mesoamerica proper. See South America) * Chibchan (Outside Mesoamerican proper. See South America) :# Paya '''Isolates''' * [[Purépecha language|Purépecha]] * Cuitlatec (extinct) * Huave * Xinca (extinct?) * Lenca (extinct) '''Proposed stocks''' * Hokan (see North America) :# Tequistlatec-Jicaque * Macro-Mayan (Penutian affiliation now considered doubtful.) :# Totonac–Tepehua :# Huave :# Mixe–Zoque :# Mayan * Macro-Chibchan :# Chibchan :# Misumalpan :# Paya (sometimes placed in Chibchan proper) :# Xinca :# Lenca ==South America== ===Kaufman (1990)=== ====Families and isolates==== Terrence Kaufman's classification is meant to be a rather conservative genetic grouping of the languages of South America (and a few in Central America). He has 118 ''genetic units''. Kaufman believes for these 118 units "that there is little likelihood that any of the groups recognized here will be broken apart". Kaufman uses more specific terminology than only ''language family'', such as ''language area'', ''emergent area'', and ''language complex'', where he recognizes issues such as partial [[mutual intelligibility]] and [[dialect continuum]]s. The list below collapses these into simply ''families''. Kaufman's list is numbered and grouped by "geolinguistic region". The list below is presented in alphabetic order. Kaufman uses an anglicized orthography for his genetic units, which is mostly used only by himself. His spellings have been retained below. {| | valign="top" width="65%" | '''Families:''' # [[Aymaran languages|Aimoré]] # [[Arauan languages|Arawán]] # [[Barbacoan languages|Barbakóan]] # [[Bora language|Bóran]] # [[Boróroan languages|Boróroan]] # [[Chapacuran languages|Chapakúran]] # [[Charrúan languages|Charrúan]] # [[Chibchan languages|Chíbchan]] # [[Chimuan languages|Chimúan]] # [[Chipaya languages|Chipaya]] # [[Choco languages|Chokó]] # [[Cholónan languages|Cholónan]] # [[Chon languages|Chon]] # [[Haki languages|Haki]] # [[Harákmbut languages|Harákmbut]] # [[Hiraháran languages|Hiraháran]] # [[Jivaroan languages|Hívaro]] # [[Jabutían languages|Jabutían]] # [[Ge languages|Je]] # [[Kamakánan languages|Kamakánan]] # [[Karajá languages|Karajá]] # [[Cariban languages|Káriban]] # [[Katakáoan languages|Katakáoan]] # [[Katukínan languages|Katukínan]] # [[Kawapánan languages|Kawapánan]] # [[Kawéskar languages|Kawéskar]] # [[Quechuan languages|Kechua]] # [[Arawakan languages|Maipúrean]] # [[Mashakalían languages|Mashakalían]] # [[Maskóian languages|Maskóian]] # [[Matacoan languages|Matákoan]] # [[Misumalpan languages|Misumalpa]] # [[Mosetén languages|Mosetén]] # [[Muran languages|Múran]] # [[Nambikuara languages|Nambikuara]] # [[Otomákoan languages|Otomákoan]] # [[Paezan languages|Páesan]] # [[Panoan languages|Pánoan]] # [[Puinavean languages|Puinávean]] # [[Purian languages|Purían]] # [[Sálivan languages|Sálivan]] # [[Samúkoan languages|Samúkoan]] # [[Zaparoan languages|Sáparoan]] # [[Tacanan languages|Takánan]] # [[Timótean languages|Timótean]] # [[Tiníwan languages|Tiníwan]] # [[Tucanoan languages|Tukánoan]] # [[Tupian languages|Tupían]] # [[Guajiboan languages|Wahívoan]] # [[Guaicuruan languages|Waikurúan]] # [[Warpe languages|Warpe]] # [[Witotoan languages|Witótoan]] # [[Yanomaman languages|Yanomáman]] # [[Yáwan languages|Yáwan]] | valign="top" width="65%" | '''Isolates or unclassified:''' # [[Aikaná language|Aikaná]] # [[Andoke language|Andoke]] # [[Awaké language|Awaké]] # [[Baenã language|Baenã]] # [[Betoi language|Betoi]] # [[Chikitano language|Chikitano]] # [[Ezmeralda language|Ezmeralda]] # [[Fulnió language|Fulnió]] # [[Gamela language|Gamela]] # [[Gorgotoki language|Gorgotoki]] # [[Guató language|Guató]] # [[Hotí language|Hotí]] # [[Iranshe language|Iranshe]] # [[Itonama language|Itonama]] # [[Jaruro language|Jaruro]] # [[Jeikó language|Jeikó]] # [[Jurí language|Jurí]] # [[Kaliana language|Kaliana]] # [[Kamsá language|Kamsá]] # [[Kanichana language|Kanichana]] # [[Kapishaná language|Kapishaná]] # [[Karirí language|Karirí]] # [[Katembrí language|Katembrí]] # [[Kayuvava language|Kayuvava]] # [[Koayá language|Koayá]] # [[Kofán language|Kofán]] # [[Kandoshi language|Kandoshi]] # [[Kolyawaya language|Kolyawaya jargon]] # [[Kukurá language|Kukurá]] # [[Kulyi language|Kulyi]] # [[Kunsa language|Kunsa]] # [[Leco language|Leko]] # [[Lule language|Lule]] # [[Maku people (disambiguation)|Maku]] # [[Mapudungu language|Mapudungu]] # [[Matanawí language|Matanawí]] # [[Movima language|Movima]] # [[Munichi language|Munichi]] # [[Natú language|Natú]] # [[Ofayé language|Ofayé]] # [[Omurano language|Omurano]] # [[Otí language|Otí]] # [[Pankararú language|Pankararú]] # [[Puelche language|Puelche]] # [[Pukina language|Pukina]] # [[Rikbaktsá language|Rikbaktsá]] # [[Sabela language|Sabela]] # [[Sechura language|Sechura]] # [[Shokó language|Shokó]] # [[Shukurú language|Shukurú]] # [[Tarairiú language|Tarairiú]] # [[Taruma language|Taruma]] # [[Tekiraka language|Tekiraka]] # [[Tikuna language|Tikuna]] # [[Trumai language|Trumai]] # [[Tushá language|Tushá]] # [[Urarina language|Urarina]] # [[Vilela language|Vilela]] # [[Wamo language|Wamo]] # [[Wamoé language|Wamoé]] # [[Warao language|Warao]] # [[Yámana language|Yámana]] # [[Yurakare language|Yurakare]] # [[Yurimangi language|Yurimangi]] |} ====Stocks==== In addition to his conservative list, Kaufman list several larger "stocks" which he evaluates. The names of the stocks are often obvious hyphenations of two members; for instance, the Páes-Barbakóa stock consists of the Páesan and Barbakóan families. If the composition is not obvious, it is indicated parenthetically. Kaufman puts question marks by Kechumara and Mosetén-Chon stocks. '''"Good" stocks:''' * [[Awaké–Kaliana languages|Awaké–Kaliana]] (Arutani–Sape) * [[Chibcha–Misumalpa languages|Chibcha–Misumalpa]] * [[Ezmeralda–Jaruro languages|Ezmeralda–Jaruro]] * [[Jurí–Tikuna languages|Jurí–Tikuna]] * [[Kechumara languages|Kechumara]] ''(=Kechua + Haki)'' (good?) * [[Lule–Vilela languages|Lule–Vilela]] * [[Mosetén–Chon languages|Mosetén–Chon]] (good?) * [[Páes–Barbakóa languages|Páes–Barbakóa]] * [[Pano–Takana languages|Pano–Takana]] * [[Sechura–Katakao languages|Sechura–Katakao]] * [[Wamo–Chapakúra languages|Wamo–Chapakúra]] '''"Probable" stocks:''' * [[Macro-Je languages|Macro-Je]] ''(=Chikitano + Boróroan + Aimoré + Rikbaktsá + Je + Jeikó + Kamakánan + Mashakalían + Purían + Fulnío + Karajá + Ofayé + Guató)'' * [[Mura–Matanawí languages|Mura–Matanawí]] '''"Promising" stocks:''' * [[Kaliánan languages|Kaliánan]] ''(=Awaké + Kaliana + Maku)'' '''"Maybe" stocks:''' * [[Bora–Witoto languages|Bora–Witoto]] * [[Hívaro–Kawapana languages|Hívaro–Kawapana]] * [[Kunsa–Kapishaná languages|Kunsa–Kapishaná]] (now abandoned) * [[Pukina–Kolyawaya languages|Pukina–Kolyawaya]] * [[Sáparo–Yawa languages|Sáparo–Yawa]] ====Clusters & networks==== {{Expand section|date=June 2008}} Kaufman's largest groupings are what he terms ''clusters'' and ''networks''. Clusters are equivalent to macro-families (or phyla or superfamilies). Networks are composed of clusters. Kaufman views all of these larger groupings to be hypothetical and his list is to be used as a means to identify which hypotheses most need testing. ==All of the Americas== ===Swadesh (1960 or earlier)=== Morris Swadesh further consolidated on Sapir's North American classification and expanded it to group all [[indigenous languages of the Americas]] in just 6 families, 5 of which were entirely based in the Americas.{{cite book| author = Mauricio Swadesh| title = Tras la huella lingüística de la prehistoria| url = https://books.google.com/books?id=IYQkVkdsKXgC&pg=PA114| year = 1987| publisher = UNAM| isbn = 978-968-36-0368-5| page = 114 }} # [[Vasco-Dene languages]] included the Eskimo–Aleut, Na-Dene, Wakashan and Kutenai families along with most of the languages of Eurasia. # Macro-Hokan roughly comprised a combination of Sapir's Hokan–Siouan and Almosan families and expanded into Central America including the [[Jicaque language]]. # Macro-Mayan comprising Mayan along with Sapir's Penutian and Aztec-Tanoan families, the [[Otomanguean languages]] and various languages of Central and South America including the [[Chibchan languages]], the [[Paezan languages]] and the [[Tucanoan languages]]. # Macro-Quechua comprising the [[Zuni language]], the [[Purépecha language]] and various languages of South America including [[Quechua languages|Quechua]], the [[Aymara language]], the [[Panoan languages]] and most of the various other languages of Patagonia and the Andes. # Macro-Carib, an almost entirely South American family including the [[Carib languages]], the [[Macro-Je languages]] and the [[Jirajara languages]], albeit including some Caribbean languages. # Macro-Arawak, a family primarily confined to South America and its component families included the [[Arawakan languages]] and the [[Tupian languages]]. However, it also was proposed to include the [[Taíno language]] in the Caribbean and the [[Timucua language]] in Florida. ===Greenberg (1960, 1987)=== [[Joseph Greenberg]]'s classificationhttps://books.google.com/books?id=rdbEBricFRUC in his 1987 book ''[[Joseph Greenberg#The languages of the Americas|Language in the Americas]]'' is best known for the highly controversial assertion that all North, Central and South American language families other than [[Eskimo–Aleut]] and [[Na-Dene]] including Haida, are part of an [[Amerind peoples|Amerind]] [[macrofamily]]. This assertion of only three major American language macrofamiles is supported by DNA evidence,https://www.nytimes.com/2012/07/12/science/earliest-americans-arrived-in-3-waves-not-1-dna-study-finds.html although the DNA evidence does not provide support for the details of his classification. # Northern Amerind ## Almosan–Keresiouan ### Almosan #### Algic #### Kutenai #### Mosan ##### Wakashan ##### Salish ##### Chimakuan ### Caddoan ### Keres ### Siouan ### Iroquoian ## (1960) joined Andean and Equatorial, but Greenberg (1987) did not) ## [[Aymara language]] ## Itucale–Sabela ### Itucale ### Mayna ### Sabela ## Cahuapana–Zaparo ### Cahuapano ### Zaparo ## Northern Bora–Uitoto #### Boro #### Uitoto #### Carib #### Kukura #### Yagua ==Mixed languages== In ''American Indian Languages: The Historical Linguistics of Native America'', [[Lyle Campbell]] describes various pidgins and trade languages spoken by the indigenous peoples of the Americas.{{cite book| author = Lyle Campbell| title = American Indian Languages: The Historical Linguistics of Native America| date = 1997-10-23| publisher = Oxford University Press, USA| isbn = 978-0-19-509427-5| pages = 18–25 }} Some of these mixed languages have not been documented and are known only by name. * [[Medny Aleut language|Medny Aleut]] (Copper Island Aleut) * [[Chinook Jargon]] * [[Broken Slavey]] (Slavey Jargon) * [[Loucheux Jargon]] * [[Michif]] (French Cree, [[Métis]], Metchif) * [[Broken Oghibbeway]] ([[Broken Ojibwa]]) * [[Basque-Algonquian Pidgin]] (spoken by the [[Basque people|Basque]]s, [[Mi'kmaq people|Micmac]]s, and [[Innu people|Montagnais]] in eastern Canada) * [[Delaware Jargon]] * [[Pidgin Massachusett]] * Jargonized [[Powhatan]] * Lingua Franca [[Creek language|Creek]] * Lingua Franca [[Apalachee language|Apalachee]] * [[Mobilian Jargon]] * [[Güegüence-Nicarao]] (formerly spoken in Nicaragua) * [[Ndjuka-Amerindian Pidgin|Carib Pidgin]] or Ndjuka-Amerindian Pidgin (Ndjuka-Trio) * [[Carib Pidgin-Arawak mixed language]] * [[Media Lengua]] * [[Catalangu]] * [[Callahuaya]] (Machaj-Juyai, Kallawaya) * [[Nheengatú]] or [[Lingua Geral Amazonica]] ("Lingua Boa," Lingua Brasílica, Lingua Geral do Norte) * [[Lingua Geral do Sul]] or [[Lingua Geral Paulista]] ([[Tupí Austral]]) * [[Labrador Eskimo Pidgin]] * [[Hudson Strait Pidgin Eskimo]] (spoken from 1750–1850) * [[Nootka Jargon]] (18th-19th centuries; later replaced by Chinook Jargon) * [[Trader Navajo]] * [[Yopará]] (Guaraní-Spanish pidgin) * [[Afro-Seminole Creole]] (variety of Gullah) * [[Haida Jargon]] * [[Kutenai Jargon]] * [[Guajiro]]-Spanish mixed language '''Lingua francas''' * [[Occaneechi language|Ocaneechi]] (spoken in Virginia and the Carolinas in early colonial times) * [[Tuscarora language]] * [[Plains sign language]] ==Linguistic areas== {{main|Linguistic areas of the Americas}} ==Notes and references== {{reflist}} ==Bibliography== * See: [[Native American languages#Bibliography]] {{Navboxes |list = {{North America topic|Languages of}} {{South America
