revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=February 2018}}
'''Read with Me''' is a reading promotion project in [[Iran]] for disadvantaged children in marginal areas of big cities and those living in remote and deprived areas of the country. The project is designed and implemented by the Institute for Research on the History of Children’s Literature in Iran.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Page|first=Liz|date=2016-06-28|title=Focus IBBY|url=https://muse.jhu.edu/article/621993|journal=Bookbird: A Journal of International Children's Literature|volume=54|issue=3|pages=83–92|doi=10.1353/bkb.2016.0099|issn=1918-6983}}</ref>
Read with Me was started as a pilot project in 2010 in a marginal area of south-east [[Tehran]] close to brick kilns where some 120 Afghan families lived.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ibby.org/awards-activities/activities/sharjah-ibby-fund/iran-sharjahibby-fund/?L=3|title=Iran - Sharjah / IBBY Fund: IBBY official website|website=www.ibby.org|language=es|access-date=2017-05-14}}</ref> Since, the project has been expanded to 19 provinces in Iran covering over 60,000 children and young adults and more than 2500 teachers, preschool tutors or volunteers. The project is funded by donations and mainly run by volunteers.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.usbby.org/list_asahi.html|title=USBBY - IBBY-Asahi Reading Promotion Award|website=www.usbby.org|access-date=2017-05-14}}</ref> In 2016, a group of tutors from [[Mazar-i-Sharif|Mazar-e-Sharif]], [[Afghanistan]] joined the project covering about 1000 children in this city and nearby villages.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://khanak.org/en/read-with-me-second-phase-in-mazar-e-sharif/|title="Read with Me" starts the new school year in Mazar-e-Sharif with motivation! {{!}} Read with Me|website=khanak.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-05-14}}</ref>
== The Course of Action == Quality books suitable for children, based on their age-group, literacy level, cultural and social condition, are selected and packed in book-bags. In every package or bag, there are handbooks for the teachers or interested parents to guide them. Two-day training workshops are organized every 3 months for teachers, librarians, and volunteers.
Reading aloud sessions are held in classes. Teachers encourage discussion and exchange of views about the story, aiming to develop critical thinking. Reading sessions are accompanied by related art and craft activities, with an emphasis on role-playing and drama.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://publishingperspectives.com/2016/04/winners-hans-christian-andersen-asahi-reading|title=At Bologna: Winners in the Hans Christian Andersen & Asahi Awards|date=2016-04-05|work=Publishing Perspectives|access-date=2017-05-14|language=en-US}}</ref> To monitor and improve the implementation, all activities are documented for further evaluation of the project.
The project has achieved to establish a system that motivates children to read<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.asahi.com/shimbun/award/ibby/2016e.html#RWM|title=IBBY-Asahi Reading Promotion Award: The Asahi Shimbun|last=Company|first=The Asahi Shimbun|website=www.asahi.com|language=ja|access-date=2017-05-14}}</ref>
== Awards and nominations ==
=== Won ===
[[IBBY-Asahi Reading Promotion Award]] 2016<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.tehrantimes.com/news/300327/Iran-s-Read-with-Me-project-honored-at-IBBY-Asahi-Reading-Promotion|title=Iran’s "Read with Me" project honored at IBBY-Asahi Reading Promotion Awards|date=2016-04-05|work=Tehran Times|access-date=2017-05-14|language=en-US}}</ref>
=== Nominated ===
[[UNESCO-Japan Prize on Education for Sustainable Development]]
[[Astrid Lindgren Memorial Award]]
== References == <!--- See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Footnotes on how to create references using<ref></ref> tags, these references will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.khanak.org/en www.khanak.org/en]
[[Category:Articles created via the Article Wizard]] [[Category:Children's literature organizations]] [[Category:Book promotion]] [[Category:2010 establishments in Iran]]

revision.comment: Update website as Reformers main domain has changed
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2014}} {{Use Australian English|date=April 2014}} {{Infobox company | name = Reformers Bookshop | logo = Reformers Bookshop logo.gif | logo_size = 200px | type = Book store | foundation = 1983 | homepage = {{URL|http://www.reformers.com.au/}} }} '''Reformers (Reformers Bookshop)''' is a [[Nonprofit organization|non-profit]]<ref>See the [http://www.abr.business.gov.au/SearchByAbn.aspx?abn=51192053225 Australian Business Register Page detailing the ownership by three charitable organisations] retrieved on 19 August 2011.</ref> [[Christian]] [[wholesaler]] and [[bookseller]] operating in [[Australasia]], plus telephone, internet and [[mail order]] worldwide.<ref>See the official Reformers Bookshop [http://reformers.org.au/ Australian website] and [http://www.reformers.co.nz/ New Zealand website]</ref>
Originally set up in 1983 as a faith-based book ministry by a married couple of [[Stanmore, New South Wales|Stanmore]] [[Baptist]] Church<ref>See both the [http://www.stanmorebaptist.org.au/ congregational website] and [http://www.abr.business.gov.au/SearchByAbnHistory.aspx?abn=17560917417 Australian Business Register History Page for Stanmore Baptist Church], both retrieved on 16 August 2011</ref> to sell [[Banner of Truth]] literature,<ref>See the [http://www.banneroftruth.org/pages/articles/article_detail.php?625 Banner of Truth article] for the history of the early years of the bookshop.</ref> Reformers expanded its range over the years and in 2007 became a Reformed Baptist/Presbyterian [[joint venture]]<ref>See the [http://www.abr.business.gov.au/(nr334xzo3ungl545c4rjmd55)/search.aspx?SearchText=37+318+848+553&StartSearch=True Australian Business Register entry]. Retrieved on 4 June 2009.</ref> in partnership with the Theological Education Committee<ref>[http://www.pcnsw.org.au/index.php/our-work/theological-education The TEC's role] was both to govern the PTC and provide representation on the Reformers Governing Committee. See also the [http://www.abr.business.gov.au/SearchByAbnHistory.aspx?abn=37318848553 Australian Business Register History Page for the Joint Venture from 1 April 2007] retrieved on 16 August 2011.</ref> of, and (from July 2009) the Trustees<ref>[http://www.pcnsw.org.au/index.php/our-work/the-property-trust Information on the Trustees of the Presbyterian Church of NSW]</ref> of, the [[Presbyterian Church of New South Wales]].<ref>[http://www.abr.business.gov.au/SearchByAbnHistory.aspx?abn=51192053225 Australian Business Register History Page for the Joint Venture from 1 July 2009] retrieved on 16 August 2011.</ref> Its stated goal is to make available the best in historic and contemporary [[Christian literature]],<ref>As noted on the [http://www.pcq.org.au/index.php?option=com_weblinks&view=category&id=18&Itemid=126 Presbyterian Church of Queensland website]</ref> and its range reflects the [[theological]] stance of its various [[joint venture]] partners i.e. [[Evangelicalism|evangelical]], [[reformed]] and conservative i.e. with a high view of the [[Bible]] as the ultimate authority in all things of which it speaks.<ref>The [http://www.pcnsw.org.au/index.php/who-we-are/beliefs Presbyterian Church of NSW] is strongly evangelical and reformed, in its doctrine, church government and theology of worship.</ref> Its senior staff are [[theologically]] trained to [[Minister (Christianity)|ministerial]] level.<ref>[http://reformers.org.au/christian-bookshop-about-reformers.html Reformers website]</ref>
Since 2007, it has grown to become the largest specialised seller of evangelical, reformed literature in Australasia, with a brochure mailing list stated to be over 20,000 copies.<ref>See the statement on [http://reformers.org.au/christian-bookshop-subscribe.html the Reformers Subscribe page.] Retrieved on 16 August 2011.</ref> In contrast with the multi-store approach of [[Koorong]] and [[Word (bookstore)|Word]], Reformers appears to have adopted a single-distribution-centre-cum-internet strategy for sales and order fulfilment.
Reformers is the sole Australian trade distributor<ref>See the article on the [http://connect09.sydneyanglicans.net/files/Reformers_bookshop.pdf Sydney Anglicans website] about the distributorship. Retrieved on 28 May 2009.</ref> for both [[The Good Book Company]],<ref>[http://www.thegoodbook.co.uk/ The Good Book Company website].</ref> with its well-known [[Christianity Explored]]<ref>[http://www.ceministries.org/resources/how-to-order/ Christianity Explored Stockist Listing]</ref> and Discipleship Explored ranges (by [[Rico Tice]] and [[Barry Cooper (author)|Barry Cooper]]), and P&R Publishing (formerly Presbyterian & Reformed Publishing).<ref>[http://www.prpbooks.com/contact.html The P&R Publishing Contact Us Page] lists Reformers as the sole Australian and New Zealand distributor.</ref> Reformers is also an Australasian trade distributor or reseller for the [[imprint (trade name)|imprint]]s of a number of other well-known evangelical and reformed [[publishing house]]s, including Christian Focus,<ref>[http://www.christianfocus.com/ Christian Focus] is a large, evangelical, Scottish publisher. Reformers is an Australian distributor - see the [http://www.christianfocus.com/distributor/list/-/-/n_t Christian Focus International Distributor List]</ref> [[Banner of Truth]], [[Baker Book House]], [[Good News Publishers|Good News Crossway]], [[Day One Christian Ministries|Day One]],<ref>Reformers is a reseller for [http://www.dayone.co.uk/content/index2.php?id=1 Day One Publications].</ref> [[Eerdmans]],<ref>See [http://www.eerdmans.com/distributors.htm#AUSTRALIA the Eerdmans Australian Distributor listing], retrieved on 16 August 2011.</ref> [[Evangelical Press]],<ref>Reformers is [http://www.epbooks.org/faqnew.php a Partnership Bookstore of Evangelical Press], and shares its theological stance.</ref> [[Founders Press]],<ref>[http://www.founders.org Founders Press] has a [[Southern Baptist]] perspective.</ref> Go Teach,<ref>[http://www.goteach.org.uk/ Go Teach website]</ref> Granted Ministries,<ref>See [http://spiritualdepression.grantedministries.org/where.html Granted Ministries International Distributor Page]</ref> [[InterVarsity Press|Inter-Varsity Press UK]], [[Ligonier Ministries]], [[Matthias Media]] and Shepherd Press. Reformers trades under a number of other names throughout Australasia including Reformers Bookshop, Reformers Christian Bookshop, Great Christian Books and Advantage Plus.<ref>[http://www.abr.business.gov.au/SearchByAbn.aspx?abn=51192053225 Australian Business Register Page for the Joint Venture from 1 July 2009] retrieved on 16 August 2011.</ref>
Reformers supplies the books, either directly or via third-party, to a number of significant Australian conferences, including the EQUIP Women's Conferences,<ref>[http://www.equip.org.au/ EQUIP website].</ref> [[Katoomba Christian Convention]], [[Sydney Anglican]] Conferences and [[Banner of Truth]] Conferences,<ref>This conference attracts ministry workers from all around Australia and New Zealand, from Presbyterian, Christian Reformed, Anglican, Congregationalist and Reformed Baptist traditions.</ref> a biennial conference of [[reformed]] speakers.
Reformers also provides books for students of various [[reformed]] [[theological college]]s,<ref>See the [http://www.actheology.edu.au/resources.php listing on the Australian College of Theology Resources Page].</ref> including the [[Presbyterian Theological Centre| Presbyterian Theological Centre Sydney]], the [[Queensland Theological College]], the [[Presbyterian Theological College| Presbyterian Theological College Melbourne]]<ref>[http://www.presbyteriancollege.org/resources.html Presbyterian Theological College, Melbourne website]</ref> and the [[Reformed Theological College| Reformed Theological College Geelong]], as part of the Geneva Foundation grants.<ref>See [http://online.ptcsydney.org/?content=fees PTC Scholarships and Bursaries] for a description of the Geneva bursaries. The Geneva Foundation is an independent charitable organisation that makes grants to eligible bodies, primarily for the advancement of religious education.</ref> It also supports Christian missions via its sale-or-return arrangements with congregations.<ref>See the Reformers Bookshop [http://reformers.org.au/christian-bookshop-about-reformers.html About Us] webpage.</ref> Reformers is a member of the Christian Bookselling Association of Australia.<ref>[http://www.cbaa.com.au CBAA website]</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Calvinism|Christianity}} *[[List of book distributors]] *[[Reformed baptist]] *[[The Good Book Company]] *[[Matthias Media]]
==Notes and references== <references />
{{Christianity in Australia}}
[[Category:Christianity in Australia]] [[Category:Bookshops of Australia]] [[Category:Presbyterian Church of Australia]] [[Category:Evangelicalism]] [[Category:Calvinist organizations established in the 20th century]] [[Category:Christian media companies]] [[Category:Religious organizations established in 1983]] [[Category:Book distributors]]

The '''Society of American Historians,''' founded in 1939, encourages and honors literary distinction in the writing of history and biography about American topics. The approximately 300 members include professional historians, independent scholars, journalists, film and documentary makers, novelists, poets, and biographers, all of whom were selected for membership based on the literary excellence as well as the intellectual strength of their writing or presentation of American history.
== Prizes and awards == {{main|Francis Parkman Prize}} {{main|James Fenimore Cooper Prize}}
The Society sponsors four awards, which are announced at its annual dinner in May:<ref>[http://sah.columbia.edu/content/prizes Society of American Historians: Prizes]. Retrieved on 29 December 2013</ref> <ref>[http://einaudi.cornell.edu/sites/default/files/2013%20SAH%20press%20release.pdf Society of American Historians Press Release]. Retrieved on 29 December 2013</ref> * The [[Francis Parkman]] Prize, given annually for the best nonfiction book in American history, is named for the nineteenth-century historian whose multi-volume work, ''France and England in North America'' (Boston, 1865–92), is widely praised for its elegant style as well as its historical depth.<ref>[http://www.bostonathenaeum.org/node/963 Noah Sheola, "Athenaeum Authors: Francis Parkman," Boston Athenaeum.] Retrieved on 13 January 2014</ref> <ref>[https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/amex/murder/sfeature/sf_parkman.html "The Parkman Family and the Murder: One Historian's Method," PBS's ''American Experience'']. Retrieved on 13 January 2014</ref> <ref>David Levin, ''History as a Romantic Art: Bancroft, Prescott, Motley, and Parkman'' (Stanford University Press, 1959)</ref> * The [[James Fenimore Cooper]] Prize, given in odd-numbered years for the best historical novel on an American theme, carries the name of the most famous American historical novelist of the nineteenth century. * The [[Allan Nevins]] Prize recognizing new scholarship is given annually to the best-written doctoral dissertation on an American subject. The winning dissertation is published by one of the Society's seventeen publisher members, which include both academic and trade presses. The prize is named for the Society's chief founder.<ref>[http://sah.columbia.edu/content/information-0 Society of American Historians: Allan Nevins Prize] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131231073921/http://sah.columbia.edu/content/information-0 |date=2013-12-31 }}. Retrieved on 29 December 2013</ref> * The [[Arthur M. Schlesinger, Jr.|Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr.]] Award, established in 2007, is given jointly with the [[Roosevelt Institute]] each year for distinguished writing in American history of enduring public significance.<ref>[http://sah.columbia.edu/content/arthur-m-schlesinger-jr-award Society of American Historians: Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. Award] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131231083238/http://sah.columbia.edu/content/arthur-m-schlesinger-jr-award |date=2013-12-31 }}. Retrieved on 29 December 2013</ref> <ref>[http://www.rooseveltinstitute.org/projects/roosevelt-awards-research-grants "Roosevelt Awards & Research Grants," Roosevelt Institute] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110513145703/http://www.rooseveltinstitute.org/projects/roosevelt-awards-research-grants |date=2011-05-13 }}. Retrieved on 13 January 2014.</ref> Schlesinger was a preeminent historian of the twentieth century as well as a public intellectual noted for giving history a voice in public affairs.<ref>[http://www.thenation.com/article/lessons-history John Hope Franklin, "The Lessons of History," ''The Nation,'' 4 December 2006]. Retrieved 13 January 2014</ref>
== History ==
The Society was founded by Allan Nevins and a few colleagues who were critical of what Nevins in a 1939 ''Saturday Review'' article called the "pedantic school" of history—academics who, he said, seemed to take pride in writing badly.<ref>Robert Middlekauff, "Telling the Story of the Civil War: Allan Nevins as a Narrative Historian," ''Huntington Library Quarterly'' 56 (Winter, 1993): 72</ref> Nevins, who taught history for over 35 years at Columbia University, was the author of more than 50 books, including an eight-volume history of the American Civil War and biographies of John D. Rockefeller, Henry Ford, and Grover Cleveland (which won the 1933 [[Pulitzer Prize for Biography or Autobiography]]). A journalist for fifteen years before coming to Columbia (he never earned a Ph.D.), Nevins was the master of a robust and readable style, and continued throughout his life to write for radio and the popular press.<ref>Gerald L. Fetner, ''Immersed in Great Affairs: Allan Nevins and the Heroic Age of American History'' (2004)</ref>
== Publications ==
In 1954, in an effort to bring good historical writing to a wide audience, the Society collaborated in establishing the magazine [[American heritage magazine|''American Heritage'']] as a popular illustrated bimonthly.<ref>Mark C. Reynolds, [http://www.americanheritage.com/content/golden-anniversary-1?page=show "Golden Anniversary," ''American Heritage,'' Nov./Dec. 2004]. Retrieved on 29 December 2013</ref> The Society has co-published several books authored by members, including ''Profiles in Leadership: Historians on the Elusive Quality of Greatness,'' edited by [[Walter Isaacson]] (W. W. Norton, 2010); ''Days of Destiny: Crossroads in American History,'' edited by [[James M. McPherson]] and [[Alan Brinkley]] (Dorling Kindersley, 2001); and ''"To the Best of My Ability": The American Presidents,'' edited by James M. McPherson (Dorling Kindersley, 2000).
== Administration ==
The Society's officers for 2018/19 are [[Ann Fabian]], president, and Jan Lewis, vice president. Its administrative office is located at Columbia University; it is supported largely by annual dues from individual and publisher members.<ref>[http://sah.columbia.edu/content/executive-board Society of American Historians: About]. Retrieved on 14 May 2018</ref> It is an affiliate of the American Historical Association.<ref>[https://www.historians.org/about-aha-and-membership/affiliated-societies/society-of-american-historians American Historical Association]. Retrieved on 12 May 2015</ref>

revision.comment: /* Variations */ Untrue or at least overly generalising, as at least one famous written version of the tale in France predates the Revolution (Anne-Marguerite Dunoyer, Lettres Historiques et Galantes, 1720).

revision.text:
{{short description|a composition by Thiuvalluvar about life, love and morals/ethics}} {{redirect|Kural|other uses|Kural (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox book | italic title = | name = Tirukkural
{{lang|ta|திருக்குறள்}} | image = திருக்குறள் தெளிவு.pdf | image_size = | alt = | caption = A typical published original Tamil version of the book | author = [[Valluvar]] | audio_read_by = | title_orig = Muppāl | orig_lang_code = | title_working = Kural | translator = | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = [[India]] | language = [[Old Tamil language|Old Tamil]] | series = [[Patiṉeṇkīḻkaṇakku]] | release_number = | subject = [[Secular ethics]] | genre = [[Poetry]] | set_in = | published = | publisher = | publisher2 = | pub_date = 1812 (first known printed edition) | english_pub_date =1840 | media_type = | pages = | awards = | isbn = | isbn_note = | oclc = | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = | followed_by = | native_wikisource = | wikisource = | notes = | exclude_cover = | website = }} {{Sangam literature}} {{wikisourcelang|ta|திருக்குறள்|Tirukkural}} The '''Tirukkural''' ({{lang-ta|திருக்குறள்}}, literally ''Sacred Verses''), or shortly '''the Kural''', is a classic [[Tamil language|Tamil]] text consisting of 1,330 couplets or [[Kural (poetic form)|Kural]]s, dealing with the everyday virtues of an individual.{{sfn|C. Blackburn, 2000|pp=449–482}}{{sfn|Pillai, 1994|p=}} It is one of the two oldest works now extant in [[Tamil Literature]] in their entirety, the other being the [[Tolkappiyam]].{{sfn|Manavalan, 2009|p=24}} Considered one of the greatest works ever written on ethics and morality, chiefly [[secular ethics]], it is known for its universality and non-denominational nature.{{sfn|Lal, 1992|pp=4333–4334}} It was authored by [[Thiruvalluvar|Valluvar]], also known in full as Thiruvalluvar. The text has been dated variously from 300 BCE to 7th century CE. The traditional accounts describe it as the last work of the third [[Sangam literature|Sangam]], but linguistic analysis suggests a later date of 450 to 500 CE.{{sfn|Zvelebil, 1975|p=124}} Traditionally praised as "the Universal Veda" and "the Universal Code of Conduct,"{{sfn|Manavalan, 2009|p=22}}{{sfn|Zvelebil, 1973|pp=155–156}} the Kural emphasizes on the vital principles of [[non-violence]], [[moral vegetarianism]] or [[veganism]],{{Ref label|A|a|none}} human brotherhood, absence of desires, path of righteousness and truth, and so forth, besides covering a wide range of subjects such as moral codes of rulers, friendship, agriculture, knowledge and wisdom, sobriety, love, and domestic life.{{sfn|Lal, 1992|pp=4333–4334}} The work is commonly quoted in vegetarian conferences, both in [[India]] and abroad.{{sfn|Sanjeevi, 1973|pp=10–16}} Considered as chef d'oeuvre of both Indian and world literature,{{sfn|Pyatigorsky, n.d.|p=515}} the Kural is one of the most important works in the [[Tamil language]] and is often called "the masterpiece of Tamil Literature."{{sfn|Manavalan, 2009|p=24}} This is reflected in some of the other names by which the text is given by, such as the Work of Three Books, Modern Veda, Divine Work, Faultless Word, and Tamil Veda.{{sfn|Manavalan, 2009|p=22}}{{sfn|Cutler, 1992|pp=}} The Kural has influenced several scholars across the ethical, social, political, economical, religious, philosophical, and spiritual spheres.{{sfn|Velusamy and Faraday, 2017|pp=7–13}}{{sfn|Sundaramurthi, 2000|p=624}} Authors influenced by the Kural include [[Ilango Adigal]], [[Kambar (poet)|Kambar]], [[Leo Tolstoy]], [[Mahatma Gandhi]], [[Albert Schweitzer]], [[Constantius Joseph Beschi]], [[Karl Graul]], [[George Uglow Pope]], [[Alexander Piatigorsky]], and [[Yu Hsi]], many of whom have translated the work into their languages. Translated into at least 40 languages as of 2014, the Kural is one of the [[List of literary works by number of translations|most widely translated works]] in the world.{{sfn|Ashraf, n.d.}} Because the life, culture and ethics of the [[Tamil people|Tamils]] are considered to be solely defined in terms of the values set by the Kural, the government and the people of [[Tamil Nadu]] alike uphold the text with utmost reverence.{{sfn|Zvelebil, 1973|pp=156-171}} Along with the [[Gita]], the Kural is a prime candidate nominated to be the national book of India, for which a declaration was passed at the [[Tamil Nadu Assembly]] in 2006.{{sfn|Velusamy and Faraday, 2017|pp=63–80}} ==Etymology== {{main|Glossary of names for the Tirukkural}} The term ''Tirukkural'' is a compound word made of two individual terms, ''tiru'' and ''kural''. ''Tiru'' is an honorific Tamil term that corresponds to the universally Indian, Sanskrit term ''sri'' meaning "holy, sacred, excellent, honorable, and beautiful."{{sfn|Sundaram, 1990|pp=7–16}} The term ''tiru'' has as many as 19 different meanings.{{sfn|Nedunchezhiyan, 1991|p=vii}} ''Kural'' means something that is "short, concise, and abridged."{{sfn|Sundaram, 1990|pp=7–16}} Etymologically, ''kural'' is the shortened form of ''kural paattu'', which is derived from ''kuruvenpaattu'', one of the two Tamil poetic forms explained by [[Tolkappiyam]], the other one being ''neduvenpaattu''.{{sfn|Kowmareeshwari, 2012a|pp=iv–vi}} According to Winslow, ''kural'' is used as a literary term to indicate "a metrical line of 2 feet, or a distich or couplet of short lines, the first of 4 and the second of 3 feet." Thus, ''Tirukkural'' literally comes to mean "sacred couplets."{{sfn|Sundaram, 1990|pp=7–16}} The Kural is unique among ancient works that it did not have a name nor did it have any mention of the author's name in it at the time of its release at the ruler's court at the city of [[Madurai]], the seat of the [[Third Sangam|Third Tamil Sangam]].{{sfn|Pope, 1886|p=i (Introduction)}} The author used the title ''Muppāl'', meaning "three divisions," to present it to the King,{{sfn|Pillai, 1972|p=3}} since the work was written about the first three of the four ancient Indian aims in life, known as ''[[Puruṣārtha|purushaarthas]]'', viz., virtue, wealth and love,{{sfn|Sundaram, 1990|pp=7–16}}{{sfn|Lal, 1992|pp=4333, 4341}} with the fourth aim, namely, salvation (''moksha''), implicitly said in the last five chapters of Book I.{{sfn|Pillai, 1972|pp=5–7}} Remaining nameless for several years after its writing, the work came to be referred to by various names in the centuries that followed. Nine traditional names had already been in use to refer to the book during the time of writing of the ''[[Tiruvalluva Maalai]]'', a eulogy written on the Kural by various poets between the 1st and 11th centuries CE.{{sfn|Zvelebil, 1973|pp=155–156}} Nevertheless, the title ''Muppāl'' remained the work's primary name until the 13th century CE.{{sfn|Aravindan, 1968|p=105}} It is estimated that the Kural has historically been known by as many as 44 names given at various periods over the millennia, making it one of the numerously titled works.{{sfn|Velusamy and Faraday, 2017|pp=54–55}} ==Organization of the work== The Kural is structured into 133 chapters, each containing 10 couplets (or kurals), for a total of 1,330 couplets.{{sfn|Kumar, 1999|pp=91–92}}{{Ref label|B|b|none}} The 133 chapters are grouped into three parts, or "books":{{sfn|Kumar, 1999|pp=91–92}}{{sfn|Mukherjee, 1999|pp=392–393}} * Book I – Aṟattuppāl (அறத்துப்பால்): [[Aram (Kural book)|Book of Virtue]] ([[Dharma]]), dealing with virtues independent of the surroundings (Chapters 1-38) * Book II – Poruṭpāl (பொருட்பால்): [[Porul (Kural book)|Book of Polity]] ([[Artha]]), dealing with virtues with respect to the surroundings (Chapters 39-108) * Book III – Kāmattuppāl (காமத்துப்பால்): [[Inbam (Kural book)|Book of Love]] ([[Kama]]), dealing with virtues involved in conjugal human love (Chapters 109-133) Each ''kural'' or couplet contains exactly seven words, known as ''cir''s, with four ''cir''s on the first line and three on the second, following the [[Kural (poetic form)|kural]] [[Poetic metre|metre]]. A ''cir'' is a single or a combination of more than one Tamil word. For example, the term ''Thirukkural'' is a ''cir'' formed by combining the two words ''thiru'' and ''kuṛaḷ''. The book on ''Aṟam'' (virtue) contains 380 verses, that of ''Poruḷ'' (wealth) has 700 and that of ''Inbam'' (love) has 250.{{sfn|Kumar, 1999|pp=91–92}} The overall organisation of the Kural text is based on seven ideals prescribed for a commoner besides observations of love.{{sfn|SSP, 2012|pp=vii–xvi}} This includes 40 couplets on God, rain, ascetics, and virtue; 200 on domestic virtue; 140 on higher yet most fundamental virtue based on grace, benevolence and compassion; 250 on royalty; 100 on ministers of state; 220 on essential requirements of administration; 130 on morality, both positive and negative; and 250 on human love and passion.{{sfn|Lal, 1992|pp=4333–4334}}{{sfn|SSP, 2012|pp=vii–xvi}} {{hidden begin |title = Outline of the Kural |titlestyle = background:lightgreen;width:60% }} ;Book I—Book of Virtue (38 chapters) * Chapter 1. The Praise of God (கடவுள் வாழ்த்து ''kaṭavuḷ vāḻttu''): Couplets 1–10 * Chapter 2. The Excellence of Rain (வான் சிறப்பு ''vāṉ ciṟappu''): 11–20 * Chapter 3. The Greatness of Ascetics (நீத்தார் பெருமை ''nīttār perumai''): 21–30 * Chapter 4. Assertion of the Strength of Virtue (அறன் வலியுறுத்தல் ''aṟaṉ valiyuṟuttal''): 31–40 * Chapter 5. Domestic Life (இல்வாழ்க்கை ''ilvāḻkkai''): 41–50 * Chapter 6. The Goodness of the Help to Domestic Life (வாழ்க்கைத்துணை நலம் ''vāḻkkaittuṇai nalam''): 51–60 * Chapter 7. The Obtaining of Sons (புதல்வரைப் பெறுதல் ''putalvaraip peṟutal''): 61–70 * Chapter 8. The Possession of Love (அன்புடைமை ''aṉpuṭaimai''): 71–80 * Chapter 9. Cherishing Guests (விருந்தோம்பல் ''viruntōmpal''): 81–90 * Chapter 10. The Utterance of Pleasant Words (இனியவை கூறல் ''iṉiyavai kūṟal''): 91–100 * Chapter 11. The Knowledge of Benefits Conferred: Gratitude (செய்ந்நன்றி அறிதல் ''ceynnaṉṟi aṟital''): 101–110 * Chapter 12. Impartiality (நடுவு நிலைமை ''naṭuvu nilaimai''): 111–120 * Chapter 13. The Possession of Self-restraint (அடக்கமுடைமை ''aṭakkamuṭaimai''): 121–130 * Chapter 14. The Possession of Decorum (ஒழுக்கமுடைமை ''oḻukkamuṭaimai''): 131–140 * Chapter 15. Not coveting another's Wife (பிறனில் விழையாமை ''piṟaṉil viḻaiyāmai''): 141–150 * Chapter 16. The Possession of Patience, Forbearance (பொறையுடைமை ''poṟaiyuṭaimai''): 151–160 * Chapter 17. Not Envying (அழுக்காறாமை ''aḻukkāṟāmai''): 161–170 * Chapter 18. Not Coveting (வெஃகாமை ''veḵkāmai''): 171–180 * Chapter 19. Not Backbiting (புறங்கூறாமை ''puṟaṅkūṟāmai''): 181–190 * Chapter 20. The Not Speaking Profitless Words (பயனில சொல்லாமை ''payaṉila collāmai''): 191–200 * Chapter 21. Dread of Evil Deeds (தீவினையச்சம் ''tīviṉaiyaccam''): 201–210 * Chapter 22. The knowledge of what is Befitting a Man's Position (ஒப்புரவறிதல் ''oppuravaṟital''): 211–220 * Chapter 23. Giving (ஈகை ''īkai''): 221–230 * Chapter 24. Renown (புகழ் ''pukaḻ''): 231–240 * Chapter 25. The Possession of Benevolence (அருளுடைமை ''aruḷuṭaimai''): 241–250 * Chapter 26. The Renunciation of Flesh-Eating (புலான் மறுத்தல் ''pulāṉmaṟuttal''): 251–260 * Chapter 27. Penance (தவம் ''tavam''): 261–270 * Chapter 28. Inconsistent Conduct (கூடாவொழுக்கம் ''kūṭāvoḻukkam''): 271–280 * Chapter 29. The Absence of Fraud (கள்ளாமை ''kaḷḷāmai''): 281–290 * Chapter 30. Veracity (வாய்மை ''vāymai''): 291–300 * Chapter 31. The not being Angry (வெகுளாமை ''vekuḷāmai''): 301–310 * Chapter 32. Not doing Evil (இன்னா செய்யாமை ''iṉṉāceyyāmai''): 311–320 * Chapter 33. Not killing (கொல்லாமை ''kollāmai''): 321–330 * Chapter 34. Instability (நிலையாமை ''nilaiyāmai''): 331–340 * Chapter 35. Renunciation (துறவு ''tuṟavu''): 341–350 * Chapter 36. Knowledge of the True (மெய்யுணர்தல் ''meyyuṇartal''): 351–360 * Chapter 37. The Extirpation of Desire (அவாவறுத்தல் ''avāvaṟuttal''): 361–370 * Chapter 38. Fate (ஊழ் ''ūḻ''): 371–380 ;Book II—Book of Wealth (70 chapters) * Chapter 39. The Greatness of a King (இறைமாட்சி ''iṟaimāṭci''): 381–390 * Chapter 40. Learning (கல்வி ''kalvi''): 391–400 * Chapter 41. Ignorance (கல்லாமை ''kallāmai''): 401–410 * Chapter 42. Hearing (கேள்வி ''kēḷvi''): 411–420 * Chapter 43. The Possession of Knowledge (அறிவுடைமை ''aṟivuṭaimai''): 421–430 * Chapter 44. The Correction of Faults (குற்றங்கடிதல் ''kuṟṟaṅkaṭital''): 431–440 * Chapter 45. Seeking the Aid of Great Men (பெரியாரைத் துணைக்கோடல் ''periyārait tuṇaikkōṭal''): 441–450 * Chapter 46. Avoiding mean Associations (சிற்றினஞ்சேராமை ''ciṟṟiṉañcērāmai''): 451–460 * Chapter 47. Acting after due Consideration (தெரிந்து செயல்வகை ''terintuceyalvakai''): 461–470 * Chapter 48. The Knowledge of Power (வலியறிதல் ''valiyaṟital''): 471–480 * Chapter 49. Knowing the fitting Time (காலமறிதல் ''kālamaṟital''): 481–490 * Chapter 50. Knowing the Place (இடனறிதல் ''iṭaṉaṟital''): 491–500 * Chapter 51. Selection and Confidence (தெரிந்து தெளிதல் ''terintuteḷital''): 501–510 * Chapter 52. Selection and Employment (தெரிந்து வினையாடல் ''terintuviṉaiyāṭal''): 511–520 * Chapter 53. Cherishing one's Kindred (சுற்றந்தழால் ''cuṟṟantaḻāl''): 521–530 * Chapter 54. Unforgetfulness (பொச்சாவாமை ''poccāvāmai''): 531–540 * Chapter 55. The Right Sceptre (செங்கோன்மை ''ceṅkōṉmai''): 541–550 * Chapter 56. The Cruel Sceptre (கொடுங்கோன்மை ''koṭuṅkōṉmai''): 551–560 * Chapter 57. Absence of Terrorism (வெருவந்த செய்யாமை ''veruvantaceyyāmai''): 561–570 * Chapter 58. Benignity (கண்ணோட்டம் ''kaṇṇōṭṭam''): 571–580 * Chapter 59. Detectives (ஒற்றாடல் ''oṟṟāṭal''): 581–590 * Chapter 60. Energy (ஊக்கமுடைமை ''ūkkamuṭaimai''): 591–600 * Chapter 61. Unsluggishness (மடியின்மை ''maṭiyiṉmai''): 601–610 * Chapter 62. Manly Effort (ஆள்வினையுடைமை ''āḷviṉaiyuṭaimai''): 611–620 * Chapter 63. Hopefulness in Trouble (இடுக்கண் அழியாமை ''iṭukkaṇ aḻiyāmai''): 621–630 * Chapter 64. The Office of Minister of State (அமைச்சு ''amaiccu''): 631–640 * Chapter 65. Power in Speech (சொல்வன்மை ''colvaṉmai''): 641–650 * Chapter 66. Purity in Action (வினைத்தூய்மை ''viṉaittūymai''): 651–660 * Chapter 67. Power in Action (வினைத்திட்பம் ''viṉaittiṭpam''): 661–670 * Chapter 68. The Method of Acting (வினை செயல்வகை ''viṉaiceyalvakai''): 671–680 * Chapter 69.
